commit_message:
Note the 90-day embargo limit

Now that Ia501817277a3fed215edd78a8035ad07a90810f0 has merged and
adds a 90-day maximum embargo period, update our instructions,
process documentation and templates accordingly. Also fix a few
locations where we failed to mention StoryBoard (now that we have
covered projects making use of it).

Change-Id: I5fd671910a44d03d25034cf1ea31fb34f695747f

subject: Support volume local cache
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 136, 'name': 'Tim Bell', 'email': 'tim.bell@cern.ch', 'username': 'tim-bell'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}, {'_account_id': 5754, 'name': 'Alex Xu', 'email': 'hejie.xu@intel.com', 'username': 'xuhj'}, {'_account_id': 8864, 'name': 'Artom Lifshitz', 'email': 'alifshit@redhat.com', 'username': 'artom'}, {'_account_id': 9555, 'name': 'Matthew Booth', 'email': 'mbooth@redhat.com', 'username': 'MatthewBooth'}, {'_account_id': 9708, 'name': 'Balazs Gibizer', 'display_name': 'gibi', 'email': 'gibizer@gmail.com', 'username': 'gibi'}, {'_account_id': 10135, 'name': 'Lee Yarwood', 'display_name': 'Lee Yarwood', 'email': 'lyarwood@redhat.com', 'username': 'lyarwood'}, {'_account_id': 11347, 'name': 'Rui Zang', 'email': 'rui.zang@yandex.com', 'username': 'rzang'}, {'_account_id': 11604, 'name': 'sean mooney', 'email': 'smooney@redhat.com', 'username': 'sean-k-mooney'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 25625, 'name': 'Tetsuro Nakamura', 'email': 'tetsuro.nakamura.bc@hco.ntt.co.jp', 'username': 'tetsuro0907'}, {'_account_id': 26458, 'name': 'Brin Zhang', 'email': 'zhangbailin@inspur.com', 'username': 'zhangbailin'}, {'_account_id': 28948, 'name': 'Liang Fang', 'email': 'liang.a.fang@intel.com', 'username': 'liang'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-10-17 03:07:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-10-17 03:40:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Lack of ['Feature Liaison'], that's why the pepe8 failed."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-10-22 14:11:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

Couple of questions and suggestions inline.

Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-10-22 14:26:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-11-01 15:02:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

How will cache resources on the host be managed? Are you going to expose these to placement? Are all the proposed cache implementations fixed size? If not, what happens if it fills up?

As I mentioned in the cinder spec you'll need additional interfaces in os-brick to support disabling the cache for live migration.

I would be opposed to any change to os-brick which modifies a block device on the host. I want to see us:

a) Expose the volume as normal in the normal place
b) Create a new overlay device to cache the volume
c) Expose the location of the new overlay device to Nova explicitly

How will this interact with encrypted volumes? I want my volume both encrypted and cached.

The mechanism as describe would not be usable by ceph volumes, as they connect directly to the qemu process without involving os-brick. This could potentially also become true of iscsi volumes in the future. Is it possible to use this feature for qemu-attached volumes?

Have you asked your users if they are willing to configure this in the guest? If we give them fast NVME SSD ephemeral disks for their guest and they configure these as cache devices, all of the above complexity goes away, and they still get the same performance benefit."}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-11-03 14:08:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-11-03 14:56:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)

Thanks all for your review. Some gibi's questions I'm not sure at this moment, may can be discussed in PTG. About questions from Matthew, I do my best to answer:
1) I originally assume the cache resource is there, and just to enable/disable in nova-cpu.conf, and don't use placement. Will discuss in PTG or weekly meeting to get yours input.
2) Cache software will treat whole cache device as a big shared pool.
All the guests in the compute node can share this cache pool. If fills up, cache software will swap the cold data out of cache. This would depend on the policy that cache software choose. Nova don't need to care about this.
3) Cache mode should be "PassThrough", so backend storage always has all the data, so no dirty data in cache. Given this, looks like we don't need to add additional interfaces in os-brick to support disabling the cache for live migration.
4) If the way luks did (overwrite symbol link) has proven problematic, I'm OK to use the way you mentioned, thanks for your info.
5) About interaction with encrypted volumes, although I haven't verified yet, but I guess cache for an encrypted volumes would be OK. Cache software will not care about whether the encryption happened inside physical disk or in backend storage, or by dm-crypt.
6) It would not be suitable for qemu-attached volumes (e.g. ceph and sheepdog). Our customer is willing to mount ceph to host first, just like other types, e.g. iscsi and NVMEof. bcache and dm-cache should have no capability to integrate with qemu, but open-cas have. Even so, open-cas still has limitation (can only integrate with a few specified version of qemu).
7) About configure cache in the guest, it would have some disadvantages: (a) cache waste. A fixed size of cache is allocated to a guest, but it may not use it very hot. Meanwhile some other guests which io is heavy but can only get a very few cache size. (b) It's not guest transparent. Need to configure cache one by one inside guest.'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-11-05 10:39:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

This isn't going to work for multiattached volumes, I'm also not sure that the use case is strong enough to even warrant this tbh."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-05 17:54:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

Agree that this is fraught with edge cases and that the win is not worth the complexity. I also think the slicing and scheduling when you approach capacity are non-trivial and not covered here.'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-11-06 02:15:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-11-06 08:46:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-06 14:35:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-11-07 08:03:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-08 15:03:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(5 comments)

Some more comments on things that need addressing.

Note that I'm not likely to +2 this as I think it's going to introduce extra complexity into our volume handling code for the supposed benefit."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-11-08 15:15:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

So, doing a little research on bcache just now... it looks like it's not totally transparent. Meaning, the backing device has to be formatted specially to be used with bcache, is that right? That would have major implications for its use in nova, such as:

 - Being able to attach a volume created with a caching compute node to one without
 - The opposite of ^
 - Creating a volume from an image
 - ...etc

Orchestrating the conversion back and forth within nova (even if it's all hidden in brick) would be a nightmare.

Unless I'm missing something about how this isn't true, I think bcache might be unsuitable for general use by nova as well, which vastly undermines the usefulness of this feature, IMHO."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-11-08 18:55:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-11-12 10:06:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(13 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-11-12 10:07:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-11-12 12:14:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I continue to like this idea in principal, although I still think it has a way to go. I'm not hearing users clamouring for the feature, though. Are you?

Major problems:

* Lack of ceph support

I see your POC brings back host-mounting of ceph volumes, but this is a retrograde step. Ceph is the most commonly used storage backend, and this would shift it to a separate, more complex, less well tested code path. I would love to see this added directly to qemu.

https://open-cas.github.io/ mentions 'Intel ® Cache Acceleration Software for QEMU', but I googled this and found only an exceptionally vague whitepaper with no detail. If Intel have actually added this to qemu we should do that instead. If not, we should encourage them to do that.

* 'Cache' metadata is undefined

Having read both the Nova and Cinder specs, I can't work out how you're supposed to specify this. Caching seems to be a feature of the compute host, so I guess this would live with the attachment, perhaps in connection_info. However, it presumably also needs to be exposed explicitly to Nova so, for eg:

- Compute API can reject an attachment because it won't work on the current compute host
- We can schedule based on the availability of caching

That said, it isn't defined if caching is a feature attached to the volume or the attachment. This needs to be very clearly defined.

Lesser problems:

* Multi-attach support

It should be obvious to the user that they're losing this. I'd be ok with this, though.

* Live migration support

I note that open-cas supports live switching of cache modes, so this could in theory be implemented by switching to pass-through prior to LM and switching back afterwards. However, I'd personally also be ok with an initial implementation which simply didn't work with LM, as long as it failed cleanly in the API."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-11-12 12:17:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-11-12 13:08:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

(13 comments)

this is closer to something i think would be reasonable.
local caching itself is not a bad idea infact i think it has many merits but this still feels light on details of how this will work.

paratactical what life cycle actions will be supported, how we will scheduler on this capability, how does this work with boot form volume. e.g. is this just for data volumes or cna it be used with the root volume.

are we making it a part of the contract that all technologies that are supported for caching must support external storage of metadata so that the cached volume does not need to be formatted. meaning that dm cache and bcach can never be used and only caching implementations like open cas can be used.

i also dont see a way for the user to indicate if they can tolerate caching e.g if for data integrity reason its ok to have a write back cache or then need to ensure its persisted via write through mode.

i would like a more worked example in the spec that adress some of those aspects.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-11-13 09:39:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)

Thanks matthew, and sean for your thought on this. Agreed almost of your comments, and will update the spec ASAP.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-11-15 10:21:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2019-11-20 10:28:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-03 09:13:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-03 09:18:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7: Patch Set 6 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-13 09:55:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2020-01-15 06:23:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

A fundamental question -- in case of multiple cache software co-exist on a host, how does nova know which one to use for a certain volume?'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-15 09:46:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 8864, 'date': '2020-01-15 16:06:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

As someone who's not really familiar with this kind of caching (not in depth anyways) or how opencas works, it took me a couple of reads and some time to think about it to grok the proposal.

As I understand it, it can be boiled down to:

1. Set a 'cachable' propery on the Cinder volume.
2. If that's set and the compute host has the correct libvirt config, do some magic to enable opencas caching for that particular volume.

My concern is around scheduling and move operations:

a. If we attach a 'cachable' volume to an instance, it sorta makes sense to fail if the host doesn't support it, as obviously the instance needs to remain on the same host. Not great UX, but I don't see a way around it.

b. However, when booting an instance with one or more 'cachable' volumes, it totally makes sense to schedule it on a host that supports caching.

c. When moving (cold migration, live migration, resize) an existing instance with 'cachable' volumes, the user would expect the caching to remain in place. With the current proposal, we have no way of guaranteeing that.

Besides those, I have other minor questions:

d. This would only be supported for libvirt, what happens when the user tries to attach a 'cachable' volume to a non-libvirt instance? Error? I guess whatever we do for encrypted volumes can be done here as well.

e. The operator might want to bill differently for the extra performance for cachable volumes, I don't see a way to do that with the current proposal. Normally we would have a flavor extra_spec for this kind of thing, but in this case I don't think that's the solution.

Sorry for all the questions (and no answers!)"}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2020-01-16 01:49:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-01-17 08:00:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@Artom @Rui Thanks for your review(No reviews got in long time:)). Your idea is good. But I have below thinking:
- When I propose this spec, it is driven by a customer which use OpenStack as private cloud. And I think private cloud is the most used scenarios of OpenStack, with less than 1000 nodes in total. Regarding public cloud, they use their own cloud OS, or deep customized OpenStack. For private cloud, it is not likely to bill the internal users of a corporation I think.
- open-cas does not support non-Linux OS, so this spec would not to support other hypervisors except Linux. libvirt is the most common used one, the code of volume local cache would only be added for libvirt. Other hypervisor would ignore "cacheable" property of a volume.
- If try to fail the volume attach operation， this would request schedule logic be ready, Nova need to schedule the VM to the correct server that with cache capability. This would be a big topic and is nice to implement in a seperate spec by somebody more familiar with Nova.
- If we just ignore the error when failed to setup cache, things would much easier. Then volume local cache would be something like "nice to have" feature, but infact it is useful, we can use aggregate to group the servers with cache capability, and schedule VM based on aggregate. This way is easier, less code change, but useful in private cloud.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-02-11 12:10:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(9 comments)

Couple of questions inline.'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2020-02-12 08:09:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-02-12 16:42:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-02-13 11:25:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-02-13 11:49:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

(8 comments)

Thanks gibi and alex. Updated spec.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-02-13 13:21:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

(7 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-02-13 14:51:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

I just wanted to update this with my current feelings before the upcoming call:

I'm glad this has been reduced to only stating support for open-cas as we learned the other cache systems would not actually be able to do what we need. AFAICT, open-cas was a closed-source dump of 35KLOC by intel less than a year ago. Building something in Nova that affects our API and which depends entirely on that other very new, very complex component to work seems like a bad idea to me, especially if Intel loses interest in maintaining that. I doubt that component exists in many (any?) LTS type distros, which means most operators can't feasibly use this.

I think that the impacts on live-migration are a major problem, in that I think live migration is a more important (Nova) feature than this caching. Things like accelerators and special hardware passthrough devices bring functionality at the expense of some features which cannot be otherwise obtained. This caching can be done differently without sacrificing live-migration, and thus it doesn't seem worth yet another "why can't I move my instance?" special case to me.

As I and others have stated, I think that this can be done easily inside the guest, eliminating many of the problems stated in the reviews here, without any impact to Nova, covering things like rbd volumes, with multiple caching systems, and in a way that makes it clear and easy how much cache resource is being used or dedicated to each instance. I don't really buy the argument that the instance owner "might not know how" or "might not want" to do the caching inside the instance. If they don't know how to run bcache or dm-cache, they're almost certainly using pre-canned images from the operator at least as their base image, which could be providing this functionality for them.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-02-13 16:57:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

This is a valid point to look at.

 > this caching. Things like accelerators and special hardware
 > passthrough devices bring functionality at the expense of some

 > done differently without sacrificing live-migration, and thus it
 > doesn't seem worth yet another "why can't I move my instance?"
 > special case to me.

As far as I understand if the cache is configured write-through then live migration works.

 > 
 > As I and others have stated, I think that this can be done easily
 > inside the guest, eliminating many of the problems stated in the
 > reviews here, without any impact to Nova, covering things like rbd
 > volumes, with multiple caching systems, and in a way that makes it

 > inside the instance. If they don't know how to run bcache or
 > dm-cache, they're almost certainly using pre-canned images from the
 > operator at least as their base image, which could be providing
 > this functionality for them.

As I see this that having a shared cache on the host might mean better utilization of the fast SSD similarly when vcpus share the same pcpu to utilize it better.'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2020-02-13 21:16:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

> > I just wanted to update this with my current feelings before the
 > > upcoming call:
 > 
 > The call was from 13:30 UTC so I guess you missed it.

I meant to commit these comments last night and realized this morning that I hadn't. The call was at 5:30am for me, unfortunately.

 > As far as I understand if the cache is configured write-through
 > then live migration works.

I see it says that in the spec, so maybe so. I thought I had seen some chat about this recently that made it sound like we'd just refuse in the API if you have a cache (I think Matt made a comment on this spec earlier too).

 > As I see this that having a shared cache on the host might mean
 > better utilization of the fast SSD similarly when vcpus share the
 > same pcpu to utilize it better.

Yep, I understand that's the only concrete benefit of doing it this way...shared cache utilization only for block-based volumes.

--Dan"}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-02-14 02:55:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 28948, 'date': '2020-02-14 03:32:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10:

Thanks gibi. Update the spec based on your comments.

@Dan Thanks. About the 3 points you mentioned:
- concern about life cycle of open-cas: open-cas is newly open-sourced, but not a new project. Previously it was a commercial software for many years. I don't have doubts about quality. 
https://www.intel.com/content/www/us/en/software/intel-cache-acceleration-software-performance.html
Every software has it's life cycle, even OpenStack itself. I believe lots of customer are using CAS(In the future only open-cas, no CAS any more I think), so I don't think Intel can/will give up open-cas. Meanwhile not sure if open-cas will go into Linux kernel or not in the future, maybe, but I don't know.

- Live migration: solved
- Compare with cache inside VM: as gibi mentioned. It is not likely to plug-in lots of physical SSDs to host OS, and assign one by one to VM. 1) cannot be shared 2) waste: if 30 SSDs plugged-in, but only 2 VM need cache, then 28 SSDs waste. So many SSDs need be prepared, but may not used."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-02-17 09:37:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2020-02-17 09:37:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

commit_message:
Support volume local cache

Use fast NVME SSD or persistent memory to cache for slow remote volumes

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/684556/
Change-Id: I5ed7626ad5c45514bcdedaf1625778e2380b3cac
Blueprint: support-volume-local-cache
Signed-off-by: Liang Fang <liang.a.fang@intel.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-25 14:52:24.000000000', 'message': "Update vulnerability:managed policy

The vulnerability:managed tag's requirement #5 for a threat analysis
was untenable, and too significant a barrier for most teams to
overcome. Even most deliverables already covered by the tag never
had one performed in the ~3.5 years since it was added. The makeup
of our community was also somewhat different at the time it was
written: we no longer have a group of volunteers like the OSSG with
bandwidth to perform and review threat analyses (arguably we never
did), but also the VMT is well-staffed and the volume of
vulnerability reports it deals with has trailed off significantly.
In 2012 we published 20 advisories, and thiw climbed to 41 issued
within 2014. In contrast, we published 2 advisories in 2018, and 3
so far in 2019. The VMT has also regularly consulted with teams on
suspected vulnerabilities (on a best-effort basis) even on
deliverables lacking the vulnerability:managed tag. As a result,
while the softening of #5 from a hard requirement to a

shouldn't be overwhelming.

Additionally, so to offset some of the risk for increased work in
tracking too many embargoed reports for long periods of time,
institute a maximum embargo period of 3 months. Also clarify that
the VMT is not responsible for tracking reports of vulnerabilities

commit_message:
Update vulnerability:managed policy

The vulnerability:managed tag's requirement #5 for a threat analysis
was untenable, and too significant a barrier for most teams to
overcome. Even most deliverables already covered by the tag never
had one performed in the ~4 years since it was added. The makeup of
our community was also somewhat different at the time it was
written: we no longer have a group of volunteers like the OSSG with
bandwidth to perform and review threat analyses (arguably we never
did), but also the VMT is well-staffed and the volume of
vulnerability reports it deals with has trailed off significantly.
In 2012 we published 20 advisories, and this climbed to 41 issued
within 2014. In contrast, we published 2 advisories in 2018, and 6
so far in 2019. The VMT has also regularly consulted with teams on
suspected vulnerabilities (on a best-effort basis) even on
deliverables lacking the vulnerability:managed tag. As a result,
while the softening of #5 from a hard requirement to a
recommendation could result in a significant increase in the number
of covered deliverables, the increase in caseload for the VMT
shouldn't be overwhelming.

Additionally, so as to offset some of the risk for increased work in
tracking too many embargoed reports for long periods of time,
institute a maximum embargo period of 3 months. Also clarify that
the VMT is not responsible for tracking reports of vulnerabilities
in any software maintained outside the OpenStack community, nor
appearing only in extended-maintenance branches, unreleased code in
master branches, pre-releases, release candidates, milestones, and
so on.

Change-Id: Ia501817277a3fed215edd78a8035ad07a90810f0

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-20 01:24:35.000000000', 'message': "Constraint dependencies for docs build

Without this patch, new library releases (even if not specifically
related to sphinx or docs) can break the docs build. For example, the
latest Werkzeug release is breaking the docs for the stable/stein branch
due to an import error that was fixed in later branches. We shouldn't be
letting new library releases affect the docs environment for the same
reason we want to control the other tox environments. This change adds
-c to the docs tox environment so ensure that all libraries installed in
this environment are known good versions.

Manual port of 13410383cf55699f756c6ce01301d7e67c65b575 edited to
reference stein instead of master.

Change-Id: Ieeb198b32a791ebf0218897b63086e04ccd34fd3
"}]
commit_message:
Constraint dependencies for docs build

Without this patch, new library releases (even if not specifically
related to sphinx or docs) can break the docs build. For example, the
latest Werkzeug release is breaking the docs for the stable/stein branch
due to an import error that was fixed in later branches. We shouldn't be
letting new library releases affect the docs environment for the same
reason we want to control the other tox environments. This change adds
-c to the docs tox environment so ensure that all libraries installed in
this environment are known good versions.

Manual port of 13410383cf55699f756c6ce01301d7e67c65b575 edited to
reference stein instead of master.

Change-Id: Ieeb198b32a791ebf0218897b63086e04ccd34fd3

[{'created': '2020-02-14 14:11:49.000000000', 'message': 'Mark NetcatTesterTestCase tests as unstable

As commented in the bug, sometimes rootwrap does not find the filter
files defined in "filters_path" configuration option. This leads to
an error during the execution of the bash command.

Change-Id: I1df041e050fe4de37476e13031f697334b82a967
Related-Bug: #1862927
'}]
commit_message:
Mark NetcatTesterTestCase tests as unstable

As commented in the bug, sometimes rootwrap does not find the filter
files defined in "filters_path" configuration option. This leads to
an error during the execution of the bash command.

Change-Id: I1df041e050fe4de37476e13031f697334b82a967
Related-Bug: #1862927

commit_message:
Force DIB_PYTHON_VERSION to 3 for Debian

Since more and more python libraries are removing support for
Python 2 in the latest versions, we need to force the version of
Python used to build the DIB Debian image to 3, at least until
DIB fully converts to Python 3.

Change-Id: I8e6f15635754ab917562d758c35a8c5f4629efdf

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-19 14:24:00.000000000', 'message': "Install gpg and sudo binary for Debian based systems

apt_key module requires gpg to be installed [1], however Debian do not
include gpg in it's minimal deployment. So we're ensuring that binary
exists before calling apt_key module

sudo is required for rootwrap and is not shipped with Debian by default

[1] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/apt_key_module.html#requirements

Change-Id: I3005bd733f64319a93ab40b51415f3cb8f51b48d
(cherry picked from commit f4c47e180b9d6324e771e75108952d261b3507a3)
"}]
commit_message:
Install gpg and sudo binary for Debian based systems

apt_key module requires gpg to be installed [1], however Debian do not
include gpg in it's minimal deployment. So we're ensuring that binary
exists before calling apt_key module

sudo is required for rootwrap and is not shipped with Debian by default

[1] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/modules/apt_key_module.html#requirements

Change-Id: I3005bd733f64319a93ab40b51415f3cb8f51b48d
(cherry picked from commit f4c47e180b9d6324e771e75108952d261b3507a3)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-10 15:05:36.000000000', 'message': 'Use stable constraint for Tempest pinned stable branches

Stable branches till stable/rocky is using python
version <py3.6. Tempest test those branch in venv
but Tempest tox use the master upper-constraint[1]
which block installation due to dependencies
require >=py3.6. For exmaple, oslo.concurrency 4.0.0
is not compatible for <py3.6.

As we pin Tempest for EM stable brach, we should be
able to use stable constraint for Tempest installation
as well as while running during run-tempest playbook.

tox.ini is hard coded to use master constraint[1] which force
run-tempest to recreate the tox env and use the master constraint.
Fix for that- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705870/

nova-live-migration test hook run_test.sh needs to use the stable
u-c so that Tempest installation in venv will use stable
branch constraint.

Modify the irrelevant-files for nova-live-migration job to run
for run_test.sh script.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/commit/bc9fe8eca801f54915ff3eafa418e6e18ac2df63/tox.ini#L14

Change-Id: I8190f93e0a754fa59ed848a3a230d1ef63a06abc
(cherry picked from commit 48a66c56441861a206f9369b8c242cfd4dffd80d)
'}]
commit_message:
Use stable constraint for Tempest pinned stable branches

Stable branches till stable/rocky is using python
version <py3.6. Tempest test those branch in venv
but Tempest tox use the master upper-constraint[1]
which block installation due to dependencies
require >=py3.6. For exmaple, oslo.concurrency 4.0.0
is not compatible for <py3.6.

As we pin Tempest for EM stable brach, we should be
able to use stable constraint for Tempest installation
as well as while running during run-tempest playbook.

tox.ini is hard coded to use master constraint[1] which force
run-tempest to recreate the tox env and use the master constraint.
Fix for that- https://review.opendev.org/#/c/705870/

nova-live-migration test hook run_test.sh needs to use the stable
u-c so that Tempest installation in venv will use stable
branch constraint.

Modify the irrelevant-files for nova-live-migration job to run
for run_test.sh script.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/commit/bc9fe8eca801f54915ff3eafa418e6e18ac2df63/tox.ini#L14

Change-Id: I8190f93e0a754fa59ed848a3a230d1ef63a06abc
(cherry picked from commit 48a66c56441861a206f9369b8c242cfd4dffd80d)

Small cleanups

* Update git URLs to use opendev.org.
* Remove obsolete sphinx instructions from setup.cfg, those are note
  used anymore.
* Change homepage to publish page of this repo.
* Remove install_command, the default works just fine.

commit_message:
Add basic molecule tests for uncovered roles

This patch adds basic molecule tests which fail until developers create
real ones. The molecule jobs are, of course, non-voting on the check and
not present on the gate. This way, the reminder will be haunting the
damned developers who prefer doing new things, sexier than doing important
molecule tests!

Change-Id: I7ff9506fed0fe4f00e80ff476189f9ea103d81d7
Signed-off-by: Gael Chamoulaud (Strider) <gchamoul@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Download Magnum images once

We delegate the post-installation steps to localhost, but we do not
limit to running them once so we download them multiple times :(

[{'created': '2020-02-18 20:15:53.000000000', 'message': 'Remove BlockStorageCinderVolume service DCN ScaleOut roles

Change-Id: I8588919cecc2be06447eba2b53b79d8d7cfc6a9e
Fixes-Bug: #1863799
'}, {'created': '2020-02-18 22:16:04.000000000', 'message': 'Remove BlockStorageCinderVolume service from certain DCN roles

The ScaleOut roles should accompany the DistributedCompute roles
which are sufficient to provide the BlockStorageCinderVolume
service.

The DistributedCompute role supports usecases without persistent
storage via Cinder while the DistributedComputeHCI supports
usecases with persistent storage via Cinder. For those usecases
we want the BlockStorageCinderVolume service to be used by
DistributedComputeHCI with Ceph but not without Ceph as that
is presently the only Cinder backend supporting active/active.

Change-Id: I8588919cecc2be06447eba2b53b79d8d7cfc6a9e
Fixes-Bug: #1863799
'}]
commit_message:
Remove BlockStorageCinderVolume service from certain DCN roles

The ScaleOut roles should accompany the DistributedCompute roles
which are sufficient to provide the BlockStorageCinderVolume
service.

The DistributedCompute role supports usecases without persistent
storage via Cinder while the DistributedComputeHCI supports
usecases with persistent storage via Cinder. For those usecases
we want the BlockStorageCinderVolume service to be used by
DistributedComputeHCI with Ceph but not without Ceph as that
is presently the only Cinder backend supporting active/active.

Change-Id: I8588919cecc2be06447eba2b53b79d8d7cfc6a9e
Fixes-Bug: #1863799

[0] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages#Summary_of_Git_commit_message_structure'}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2019-12-25 18:57:19.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

Other than that, code looks good and works as expected. Great work!"}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2019-12-26 12:03:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 31213, 'date': '2019-12-26 13:15:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6413, 'date': '2019-12-26 15:20:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

LGTM!'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2020-01-15 13:14:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I might be doing something wrong but when I cherry-picked this change set on current master in a devstack and ran 'sudo pip install -e .' from /opt/stack/python-manilaclient, although 'openstack share set' and 'openstack share unset' commands get added, I'm getting the following from 'openstack share list':

 $ openstack share list
__init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'metavar'

And it isn't actually listing the shares as it did before the cherry-pick."}, {'account_id': 18058, 'date': '2020-01-15 13:30:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Hey Tom, I tested it now by cherry-picking to current master (2816dc6b) and `sudo python setup.py install`, and I'm facing the same issue.
Maybe we both are doing something wrong..."}, {'account_id': 31213, 'date': '2020-01-15 14:03:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 31213, 'date': '2020-01-15 14:06:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Hi Tom & Lucio, thanks for pointing that out, I faced the same issue now and I think I found where I broke it. Please try again when you can :)'}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2020-01-15 17:16:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Hi Tom & Lucio, thanks for pointing that out, I faced the same issue now and I think I found where I broke it. Please try again when you can :)

Fixed.  I'm going to run the commands a bit more before voting on this one, but thanks in advance for the contribution."}, {'account_id': 18058, 'date': '2020-01-17 17:59:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

Thank you Maari, I tested it and it's working fine!"}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2020-01-19 12:33:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

Thanks, Maari!'}, {'account_id': 18058, 'date': '2020-01-21 21:32:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Hi Maari,

There are some issues similar to the ones you fixed on share type commands patch. Given a share named 'share1':

1. After running `openstack share set --description foo share1` followed by `openstack share set --description '' share1`, the description is still 'foo'.
2. After running `openstack share set --name '' share1`, the share name is still 'share1'."}, {'account_id': 9003, 'date': '2020-01-22 10:54:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 31213, 'date': '2020-01-22 13:05:00.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 31213, 'date': '2020-01-22 13:29:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 18058, 'date': '2020-01-22 20:23:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Implement osc share set/unset commands

In this patch set we add the implementation
for openstack share set and openstack share unset command.
These commands are used to change share properties
and replace the manila update and manila metadata commands.

Partially-implements: bp openstack-client-support
Change-Id: Ic09802fa5dc9c7f0180341397c2740ac0cadbcd4

[{'created': '2020-01-24 17:48:46.000000000', 'message': "DNM: Test network_data.json schema

This patch beefs up the MetadataTest functional test cases to use a real
instance instead of a database shell. This way the tests see real data
in the metadata service like a real network_data.json.

This allows to assert that the nova generated network_data.json is
conforming to the jsonschema stored in the nova tree.

TODO:
* squash it to the schema patch
* figure out why jsonutils.load() fails while json.load() doesn't in
functional-py37.
* figure out a way to do the same with the config_drive.json

Change-Id: I9f3a6858b51d9fd438a753922895c9cb8e4d0e73
"}]
commit_message:
DNM: Test network_data.json schema

This patch beefs up the MetadataTest functional test cases to use a real
instance instead of a database shell. This way the tests see real data
in the metadata service like a real network_data.json.

This allows to assert that the nova generated network_data.json is
conforming to the jsonschema stored in the nova tree.

TODO:
* squash it to the schema patch
* figure out why jsonutils.load() fails while json.load() doesn't in
functional-py37.
* figure out a way to do the same with the config_drive.json

Change-Id: I9f3a6858b51d9fd438a753922895c9cb8e4d0e73

commit_message:
Mask the token used to allow access to consoles

Hide the novncproxy token from the logs.

When backported this patch needs to be extended to handle the same issue
in the consoleauth service.
Conflicts:
      nova/tests/unit/console/test_websocketproxy.py
It is due to If1b6e5f20d2ea82d94f5f0550f13189fc9bc16c4 is only
implemented in rocky

Co-Authored-By:paul-carlton2 <paul.carlton2@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By:Tristan Cacqueray <tdecacqu@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I5b8fa4233d297722c3af08176901d12887bae3de

[{'created': '2020-02-06 15:05:11.000000000', 'message': "Fix timeseries in redfish parser

While trying to enable the redfish job in the CI we found:
`Duplicated timeseries in CollectorRegistry: {'baremetal_fan_status'}`,
this is due to the fact that  we were creating multiple `Gauge` for
the metric and Prometheus does not support this.

We should pre-create the Gauge and update with the different sets of
labels and values that were collected.

Change-Id: I4f4ea8e580ccb439afa7c8e14fabb94c2d124b17
"}, {'created': '2020-02-11 09:54:15.000000000', 'message': "Fix timeseries in redfish parser

While trying to enable the redfish job in the CI we found:
`Duplicated timeseries in CollectorRegistry: {'baremetal_fan_status'}`,
this is due to the fact that  we were creating multiple `Gauge` for
the metric and Prometheus does not support this.

We should pre-create the Gauge and update with the different sets of
labels and values that were collected.

Change-Id: I4f4ea8e580ccb439afa7c8e14fabb94c2d124b17
"}]
commit_message:
Fix timeseries in redfish parser

While trying to enable the redfish job in the CI we found:
`Duplicated timeseries in CollectorRegistry: {'baremetal_fan_status'}`,
this is due to the fact that  we were creating multiple `Gauge` for
the metric and Prometheus does not support this.

We should pre-create the Gauge and update with the different sets of
labels and values that were collected.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-13 12:48:02.000000000', 'message': "Force facts cache refreshing before upgrade.

When upgrading from Rocky to Stein, an upgrade of the operating system is
performed. This upgrade from RHEL7 to RHEL8 implies the removal of the
default /usr/bin/python binary. As the facts cache is enabled, Ansible's
strategy does not consider to upgrade facts and therefore we try to run the
ansible playbook using the old python binary when running the upgrade.
This fails with the error: /usr/bin/python: No such file or directory.

This patch makes use of the meta task clear_facts right before run the
facts gathering for the Overcloud nodes. This way, we make sure that we
are using the right python binary.

Closes-Bug: #1856313
Change-Id: I87974e88c38b42e90bc3cd801fcf1deaf268720c

commit_message:
Force facts cache refreshing after OS upgrade.

When upgrading from Rocky to Stein, an upgrade of the operating system is
performed. This upgrade from RHEL7 to RHEL8 implies the removal of the
default /usr/bin/python binary. As the facts cache is enabled, Ansible's
strategy does not consider to upgrade facts and therefore we try to run the
ansible playbook using the old python binary when running the upgrade.
This fails with the error: /usr/bin/python: No such file or directory.

This patch makes use of the setup task in combination with clear_facts
right after rebooting to upgrade the operating system, to ensure that
the facts are gathered and refreshed for the Overcloud node just upgraded.
This way, we make sure that we are using the right python binary.

Closes-Bug: #1856313
Change-Id: I87974e88c38b42e90bc3cd801fcf1deaf268720c
(cherry picked from commit f632ea38ac1f5c68d0659d5a8d0fb51bf7844eb4)
(cherry picked from commit 14db20baee3529b223a87e9f73279c6034a47427)

commit_message:
[stable-only] Cap horizon to Train version

networking-odl and networking-bagpipe gate jobs fails with version
conflicts due to bgpvpn installs latest horizon and its dependencies
are not aligned with the stable branch's upper constraints.

Change-Id: Ibd35cec847a2b1b92ec50517910f4309484e59c7

commit_message:
Force facts cache refreshing after OS upgrade.

When upgrading from Rocky to Stein, an upgrade of the operating system is
performed. This upgrade from RHEL7 to RHEL8 implies the removal of the
default /usr/bin/python binary. As the facts cache is enabled, Ansible's
strategy does not consider to upgrade facts and therefore we try to run the
ansible playbook using the old python binary when running the upgrade.
This fails with the error: /usr/bin/python: No such file or directory.

This patch makes use of the setup task in combination with clear_facts
right after rebooting to upgrade the operating system, to ensure that
the facts are gathered and refreshed for the Overcloud node just upgraded.
This way, we make sure that we are using the right python binary.

Closes-Bug: #1856313
Change-Id: Ia1fa60c22e482ab14a509730cf93634772e077a7
(cherry picked from commit 598cf6977fcc37b1b4bcc1463b6c7e80f7037b5e)

commit_message:
Ensure bc package is installed for l3 ping tests.

When running the l3 ping tests we get the following
error: bc: command not found.
Let's make sure the package is present in the system
when generating the scripts.

Change-Id: I32ad402dc7e42d85e574bf1273664bc7d6d1f9a5

subject: Temporarily make namespace arg optional
messages: [{'account_id': 6928, 'date': '2020-02-17 16:45:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-02-18 09:28:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-02-20 11:09:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nSeems as good a solution as any'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-17 16:45:32.000000000', 'message': "Temporarily make namespace arg optional

In order to fix the referenced bug, we need to register cli args on
the global config object. Unfortunately, that causes issues because
our consumers are re-calling the conf object in their enforcers due
to the way we used to handle cli args. Specifically, the conf call
in the consumer fails because the namespace arg from oslo.policy is
registered as required, but they don't pass it to the conf call.

Long-term we want to stop having consumers call the conf object at
all, but in the meantime we need to provide a migration path that
doesn't break them. This change registers the namespace arg as
optional on the conf object and temporarily moves the required check
to oslo.policy. This will allow us to maintain the existing behavior
for our cli tools while not breaking consumers who haven't migrated
to the new cli arg behavior.

Note that we do have unit test coverage of this behavior[0], so we
can be reasonably confident the explicit check is maintaining
compatibility.

Change-Id: I34ce1dd15c464bec319e51d3e217e26554f1a944
Closes-Bug: 1863637
Related-Bug: 1849518
0: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/6e2fe3857367eb2b3e2d2e92121a408e1ff89ea4/oslo_policy/tests/test_generator.py#L500
"}]
commit_message:
Temporarily make namespace arg optional

In order to fix the referenced bug, we need to register cli args on
the global config object. Unfortunately, that causes issues because
our consumers are re-calling the conf object in their enforcers due
to the way we used to handle cli args. Specifically, the conf call
in the consumer fails because the namespace arg from oslo.policy is
registered as required, but they don't pass it to the conf call.

Long-term we want to stop having consumers call the conf object at
all, but in the meantime we need to provide a migration path that
doesn't break them. This change registers the namespace arg as
optional on the conf object and temporarily moves the required check
to oslo.policy. This will allow us to maintain the existing behavior
for our cli tools while not breaking consumers who haven't migrated
to the new cli arg behavior.

Note that we do have unit test coverage of this behavior[0], so we
can be reasonably confident the explicit check is maintaining
compatibility.

Change-Id: I34ce1dd15c464bec319e51d3e217e26554f1a944
Closes-Bug: 1863637
Related-Bug: 1849518
0: https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/6e2fe3857367eb2b3e2d2e92121a408e1ff89ea4/oslo_policy/tests/test_generator.py#L500

commit_message:
Update the minversion parameter.

Update the minversion parameter to use the python -m pip to install
python packages:

https://tox.readthedocs.io/en/latest/changelog.html#id185

It's recommend to use this. Remove the useless install_command
parameter.

Change-Id: Ie1c6c65ee941509a7cec1472e798090ad00d52d7

commit_message:
Ensure python3-hvac is installed for charms with encypt option

The referenced bug is essentially: make vault:secrets relation to vault
but keep the 'encrypt' option as False. In this case, the Context
handling code in charm-helpers is expecting python3-hvac to be
available, but it is only installed if the encrypt option is set to
True.  Hence the charm crashes.  This resolves that crash.

Note the related charm-helpers fix [1].

[1]: https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/431

Change-Id: Ic02d4d4d3c3b423fa28cd171b126ed4a444fc646
Closes-bug: #1862085

Ensure python3-hvac is installed for charms with encypt option

The referenced bug is essentially: make vault:secrets relation to vault
but keep the 'encrypt' option as False. In this case, the Context

True.  Hence the charm crashes.  This resolves that crash.

Note the related charm-helpers fix [1].

commit_message:
Ensure python3-hvac is installed for charms with encypt option

The referenced bug is essentially: make vault:secrets relation to vault
but keep the 'encrypt' option as False. In this case, the Context
handling code in charm-helpers is expecting python3-hvac to be
available, but it is only installed if the encrypt option is set to
True.  Hence the charm crashes.  This resolves that crash.

Note the related charm-helpers fix [1].

[1]: https://github.com/juju/charm-helpers/pull/431

Change-Id: I92773b7c1f48d456091062751e69581fabe4c5f3
Closes-bug: #1862085

commit_message:
Add bug note to wheelhouse.txt to track pinning of python-zipp

This patch adds a bug note to track the unpinning of zipp.

(Note the bug is related, as closing the bug will be when zipp can
be unpinned.)

Related-Bug: #1862186

commit_message:
Deprecate Hyper-V integrations

Per http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-February/012646.html

Deprecates support for deploying with Hyper-V integrations.
In Victoria support for these will be removed from Kolla Ansible.

This is dictated by lack of interest and maintenance.

Change-Id: Ic214699e0e501868e453c76929eef740e92ab90f

> What indicates that EC2 API isn't maintained upstream?  I see that
 > during the time of this Review, there were commits to EC2 API on

 > on Oct 16, 24, then a break until Feb 5, with more commits on Feb
 > 12, and 13.
 > 
 > I also see no mention of a deprecation in https://github.com/openstack/ec2-api

no, we remove support for ec2 api from tripleo"}]

commit_message:
Deprecate EC2 API

The OpenStack EC2 API project isn't maintained upstream, therefore
we deprecate it.

Change-Id: Ieb108a363cecafe3407d0dd505947c99bb24226c

commit_message:
[OVN] Set 'unknown' address properly when port sec is disabled

Previous to this patch, the 'unknown' address was added to the
OVN Logical_Switch_Port row. However, the '<ip> <mac1> <macN>'
was still there so the port security was not really disabled.

The correct behavior is to set the 'addresses' field to 'unknown'
and remove everything else.

Change-Id: I0b84f41865e3fdea49cf169df5431249c35f5ff8
Closes-Bug: #1728886
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2020-02-19 08:37:57.000000000', 'message': "bug-fix: 'bytes' type in python3 cause command fail

'str' type in python2 is 'bytes' type in python3,
when use python3, we will get a prefix 'b':

sudo ip netns exec b'qrouter-39cc2b45-a27c-49c5-94a6-26443a49ac63' ip
neigh
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
*** Failed to run 'sudo ip netns exec
b'qrouter-39cc2b45-a27c-49c5-94a6-26443a49ac63' ip neigh': Command 'sudo
ip netns exec b'qrouter-39cc2b45-a27c-49c5-94a6-26443a49ac63' ip neigh'
returned non-zero exit status 1.

The message above is raised by running tools/worlddump.py with python3.

Change-Id: Ic254af86fa27729839f00c0ad4a5bbbc9e545a09
"}]
commit_message:
bug-fix: 'bytes' type in python3 cause command fail

'str' type in python2 is 'bytes' type in python3,
when use python3, we will get a prefix 'b':

sudo ip netns exec b'qrouter-39cc2b45-a27c-49c5-94a6-26443a49ac63' ip
neigh
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
*** Failed to run 'sudo ip netns exec
b'qrouter-39cc2b45-a27c-49c5-94a6-26443a49ac63' ip neigh': Command 'sudo
ip netns exec b'qrouter-39cc2b45-a27c-49c5-94a6-26443a49ac63' ip neigh'
returned non-zero exit status 1.

The message above is raised by running tools/worlddump.py with python3.

Change-Id: Ic254af86fa27729839f00c0ad4a5bbbc9e545a09

messages:
[{'account_id': 31574, 'date': '2020-02-05 10:40:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 10068, 'date': '2020-02-05 10:40:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html
Commit Messages: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/GitCommitMessages"}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2020-02-18 10:21:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2020-02-19 11:01:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

This is a good patch to add.  However, I wonder if the following options should be included in the patch as well to 'round' out the config around live_migration timeouts:

    live_migration_downtime
    live_migration_downtime_steps
    live_migration_downtime_delay

This would allow full control?

Also, as noted, the timeout appears to be per GB of data, not the entire transfer?"}, {'account_id': 31574, 'date': '2020-02-19 15:46:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 31574, 'date': '2020-02-19 16:38:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > This is a good patch to add.  However, I wonder if the following
 > options should be included in the patch as well to 'round' out the
 > config around live_migration timeouts:
 > 
 > live_migration_downtime
 > live_migration_downtime_steps
 > live_migration_downtime_delay
 > 
 > This would allow full control?
 > 
 > Also, as noted, the timeout appears to be per GB of data, not the
 > entire transfer?

In the patch 2 I used full comment, so we avoid this kind of misunderstanding. Hopefully that will make more sense to anyone reading config descriptions.

Included also all 3 live_migration_downtime.* config parameters."}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2020-02-19 16:49:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

charm-recheck-full'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2020-02-20 11:16:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

LGTM -- thanks for the patch!'}]

[{'account_id': 28354, 'date': '2019-02-15 01:18:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-02-15 05:47:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-27691 : FAILURE in 3h 47m 30s'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2019-02-15 06:54:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

Hmm, I guess exclude the deleted DB record is OK to do, but I don't see it have anything to do with your situation. Could you be more specific about what you did? I tried changing the ``compute_driver`` from libvirt.LibvirtDriver to fake.FakeDriver (this is what I can do for testing because I do not have any other hypervisors). Then after I restart the compute service the compute_node record in the DB got updated, the ``hypervisor_type`` field changed to ``fake`` and did not got deleted, when I change back to LibvirtDriver, it changed back too. Does Ironic driver do different thing?"}, {'account_id': 28354, 'date': '2019-02-15 07:25:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

one ironic nova compute  manages multi bm nodes, and one bm node regard as a hypervisor. so the 'ironic/driver.py' need to check the compute type as 'libvirt/dirver.py' don't do this.

so  changing `compute_driver` from libvirt.LibvirtDriver to fake.FakeDriver will not repeat the problem, you can try  change 'compute_driver' form ironic.IronicDriver to  libvirt.LibvirtDriver"}, {'account_id': 26515, 'date': '2019-02-15 08:36:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/637083/1 : SUCCESS in 2h 29m 31s'}, {'account_id': 28354, 'date': '2019-02-18 01:20:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@ Zhenyu Zheng
the following is my truble shoot

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/virt/ironic/driver.py
> def _refresh_hash_ring(self, ctxt):
> service_list = objects.ServiceList.get_all_computes_by_hv_type(ctxt, self._get_hypervisor_type())

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/objects/service.py
>> def get_all_computes_by_hv_type(cls, context, hv_type):
      db_services = db.service_get_all_computes_by_hv_type(context, hv_type, include_disabled=False)

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/api.py
>>> def service_get_all_computes_by_hv_type(context, hv_type, include_disabled=False):
           return IMPL.service_get_all_computes_by_hv_type(context, hv_type, include_disabled=include_disabled)

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py
>>>> def service_get_all_computes_by_hv_type(context, hv_type,
                                        include_disabled=False):
    query = model_query(context, models.Service, read_deleted="no").filter_by(binary='nova-compute')
    if not include_disabled:
        query = query.filter_by(disabled=False)
    query = query.join(models.ComputeNode, models.Service.host == models.ComputeNode.host).filter(models.ComputeNode.hypervisor_type == hv_type).distinct('host')
    return query.all()
	# the query doesn't exclude the deleted DB record，so the service_list will include the services which changed type from ironic to livirt'}, {'account_id': 15888, 'date': '2019-02-18 01:39:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> @ Zhenyu Zheng
 > the following is my truble shoot
 >

 > > def _refresh_hash_ring(self, ctxt):
 > > service_list = objects.ServiceList.get_all_computes_by_hv_type(ctxt,
 > self._get_hypervisor_type())
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/objects/service.py
 > >> def get_all_computes_by_hv_type(cls, context, hv_type):
 > db_services = db.service_get_all_computes_by_hv_type(context,
 > hv_type, include_disabled=False)
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/api.py
 > >>> def service_get_all_computes_by_hv_type(context, hv_type,
 > include_disabled=False):
 > return IMPL.service_get_all_computes_by_hv_type(context, hv_type,
 > include_disabled=include_disabled)
 > 
 > https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py
 > >>>> def service_get_all_computes_by_hv_type(context, hv_type,
 > include_disabled=False):
 > query = model_query(context, models.Service, read_deleted="no").filter_by(binary='nova-compute')
 > if not include_disabled:
 > query = query.filter_by(disabled=False)
 > query = query.join(models.ComputeNode, models.Service.host ==
 > models.ComputeNode.host).filter(models.ComputeNode.hypervisor_type
 > == hv_type).distinct('host')
 > return query.all()
 > # the query doesn't exclude the deleted DB record，so the
 > service_list will include the services which changed type from
 > ironic to livirt

Yes, I understand the thing with DB deleted row, What I don't understand is how that row changed to deleted!=0, because as I mentioned in my previous comments, I tested change virt type from libvirt to fake and then changed back, there were no deleted rows, the field of ``hypervisor_type`` updated according to my config when I restart my service, so there is no ``deleted`` rows. I was wondering if there is some different logic in ironic driver, since I don't have it and cannot test on it. Could explain that part, I mean, how did update hypervisor_type leading to an deleted record and a new record in Ironic, because it did not happen in libvirt driver.'}, {'account_id': 28354, 'date': '2019-02-18 05:40:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

 > > == hv_type).distinct('host')
 > > return query.all()
 > > # the query doesn't exclude the deleted DB record，so the
 > > service_list will include the services which changed type from
 > > ironic to livirt
 > 
 > Yes, I understand the thing with DB deleted row, What I don't
 > understand is how that row changed to deleted!=0, because as I
 > mentioned in my previous comments, I tested change virt type from
 > libvirt to fake and then changed back, there were no deleted rows,
 > the field of ``hypervisor_type`` updated according to my config
 > when I restart my service, so there is no ``deleted`` rows. I was
 > wondering if there is some different logic in ironic driver, since
 > I don't have it and cannot test on it. Could explain that part, I
 > mean, how did update hypervisor_type leading to an deleted record
 > and a new record in Ironic, because it did not happen in libvirt
 > driver.

#compute service has a periodic_task to update_available_resource, Delete orphan compute node not reported by driver but still in db
 > nova/compute/manager.py 
    @periodic_task.periodic_task(spacing=CONF.update_resources_interval)
    def update_available_resource(self, context, startup=False)
        try:
          nodenames = set(self.driver.get_available_nodes())
        except exception.VirtDriverNotReady:
            LOG.warning("Virt driver is not ready.")
            return

        # Delete orphan compute node not reported by driver but still in db
        for cn in compute_nodes_in_db:
            if cn.hypervisor_hostname not in nodenames:
                LOG.info("Deleting orphan compute node %(id)s "
                         "hypervisor host is %(hh)s, "
                         "nodes are %(nodes)s",
                         {'id': cn.id, 'hh': cn.hypervisor_hostname,
                          'nodes': nodenames})
                cn.destroy()
                self.rt.remove_node(cn.hypervisor_hostname)
                # Delete the corresponding resource provider in placement,
                # along with any associated allocations and inventory.
                self.reportclient.delete_resource_provider(context, cn,
                                                           cascade=True)
						
 # in ironic driver, `get_available_nodes` need to  `_refresh_cache`
 >> nova/virt/ironic/driver.py
    def get_available_nodes(self, refresh=False):
	    self._refresh_cache()
		
 # then `_refresh_cache` will do `_refresh_hash_ring`，this hash_ring include the deleted service
  >>> nova/virt/ironic/driver.py
    def _refresh_cache(self):
        ctxt = nova_context.get_admin_context()
        self._refresh_hash_ring(ctxt) # this hash_ring include the deleted service
        instances = objects.InstanceList.get_uuids_by_host(ctxt, CONF.host)
        node_cache = {}
		
		# get all the bm-nodes from ironic,then check every nodes
        for node in self._get_node_list(fields=_NODE_FIELDS, limit=0): 
            if node.instance_uuid in instances:
                node_cache[node.uuid] = node
            elif (node.instance_uuid is None and
                  CONF.host in
                  self.hash_ring.get_nodes(node.uuid.encode('utf-8'))): 
				 # in this case,because the hash_ring has deleted services，some nodes will belong to deleted services，so ironic types service can't manange all the nodes 
                node_cache[node.uuid] = node'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-03-05 21:09:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Fix query method for nova compute services by compute_driver types

bug:the nova compute services have been changed types of compute_driver
with old host name can still be queried by old type.

The sevice is not deleted  in the 'Service' table, due to  it's host 
name dosen't change. But the old 'hv_type' compute nodes which once been
managed by the sevice are deleted in the 'ComputeNode' table.

the query joins Service table and ComputeNode table can not filter the 
service whose driver type has been changed  


Closes-Bug: #1815849

Change-Id: I14598bd125cb67e68262b67c0afad5e1da03d5c3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-02 18:56:35.000000000', 'message': "Strip siblings from .egg-info/requires.txt

When we install siblings, we remove the sibling references from the
constraints file so that the constraints don't conflict with the git
version at install time. However, at runtime the stated requirements
version can also conflict with the version found in the git repo.
Programs using entrypoints such as python-openstackclient can then have
a problem running, since pkg_resources dutifully reports that the
version installed does not match the version required.

However, when we're doing siblings installation, we know what we're
doing, and that we want to use the version from git regardless of what
is listed in requirements.txt.

Strip version information from the entries in the project's egg-info
requires.txt file after installing siblings so that we don't have
clashing entrypoint version issues.

Change-Id: Ifafd9cc8635ab1eef42e8576fccaa922f2933ccd
"}]
commit_message:
Strip siblings from .egg-info/requires.txt

When we install siblings, we remove the sibling references from the
constraints file so that the constraints don't conflict with the git
version at install time. However, at runtime the stated requirements
version can also conflict with the version found in the git repo.
Programs using entrypoints such as python-openstackclient can then have
a problem running, since pkg_resources dutifully reports that the
version installed does not match the version required.

However, when we're doing siblings installation, we know what we're
doing, and that we want to use the version from git regardless of what
is listed in requirements.txt.

Strip version information from the entries in the project's egg-info
requires.txt file after installing siblings so that we don't have
clashing entrypoint version issues.

Change-Id: Ifafd9cc8635ab1eef42e8576fccaa922f2933ccd

subject: Add support for caching pkg_resources data
messages:
[{'account_id': 2, 'date': '2017-06-03 14:22:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2017-06-03 15:10:36.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-06-03 17:00:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified-1

Build failed (check pipeline).  For information on how to proceed, see http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#automated-testing

- gate-pbr-docs-ubuntu-xenial http://docs-draft.openstack.org/30/470630/2/check/gate-pbr-docs-ubuntu-xenial/9d975b4//doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 2m 32s
- gate-pbr-pep8-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/30/470630/2/check/gate-pbr-pep8-ubuntu-xenial/14c8f33/ : SUCCESS in 4m 23s
- gate-pbr-python27-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/30/470630/2/check/gate-pbr-python27-ubuntu-xenial/adf05f1/ : SUCCESS in 2m 47s
- gate-pbr-python35 http://logs.openstack.org/30/470630/2/check/gate-pbr-python35/6507fc8/ : FAILURE in 2m 09s
- gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-pbr-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/30/470630/2/check/gate-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src-pbr-ubuntu-xenial/0421a2e/ : SUCCESS in 1h 48m 12s
- gate-pbr-pypy http://logs.openstack.org/30/470630/2/check/gate-pbr-pypy/d4d37d6/ : SUCCESS in 3m 22s (non-voting)
- gate-pbr-installation-dsvm-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/30/470630/2/check/gate-pbr-installation-dsvm-ubuntu-xenial/91803ae/ : SUCCESS in 19m 24s
- gate-pbr-installation-dsvm-upstream-ubuntu-xenial http://logs.openstack.org/30/470630/2/check/gate-pbr-installation-dsvm-upstream-ubuntu-xenial/5aa706a/ : SUCCESS in 19m 18s'}, {'account_id': 4190, 'date': '2017-06-03 18:36:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

I don't see a spec tied into this; I think we should have one because there are some key, deep questions about this that concern me.

Putting that aside for a second, you have a race condition with file IO in the cache, please make sure you use atomic operations (or simulate as close as you can get on win32 platforms).

Back to the high level questions though; how are you going to expose to users - in our case developers doing adhoc installs, and operators running automation tooling - enough information to discover (without tedious code searching etc) false hit and misses:

e.g. when someone removes (whether with setuptools, pip, or even by hand) a pkg_resource entry, our cache will still contain it, which will lead to a false hit; similarly when the cache hasn't been rebuilt after an install, it will have a false miss. We're going to spend a lot of time answering questions about that - and thats only us, not the folk having to learn about our unsynchronised cache.

That said, I want to support the experiment, so I'm not -2ing - but I think these questions are *very* important."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2017-06-04 14:52:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Totally agree on the concern and that we need to investigate deeply.

My thinking so far is that, since nothing will ever create this cache automatically (pbr install is a new command nobody would be otherwise using, as would pbr rebuild) - that we'd expose it as "if you are having performance problems due to slow/laggy startup of the openstack command, you can create a cache with $blah. But be warned of the following issues"

We _definitely_ should not just magical the thing in place in a way where it would be running without the user knowing it was running.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2017-12-18 03:19:17.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Jenkins with the following votes:

* Verified-1 by Jenkins (3)
'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2018-09-17 15:51:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Is this permanently stalled? I don't have the context of this change so I'm inclined to think yes and abandon it, but maybe I should be looking at picking it up?"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-02-20 11:17:07.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

[{'created': '2017-06-03 14:22:10.000000000', 'message': "Add support for caching pkg_resources data

Add two sub-commands to pbr:

  rebuild - scans pkg_resources info and writes a json cache file
  install -  runs pip install then rebuilds the cache file

Then, add support to the version fetching code to read from the cache
file if it's present.

The cache file contains information both on packages and their versions
as well as all of the entrypoints registered on the system.

pbr.pkg_cache has a get_cache function that can be used by other
things, such as potentially stevedore, to try reading from the cache
before they try reading from pkg_resources.

Change-Id: Id4edd373cc2546f1457596ba8a7ffa9176728823
"}, {'created': '2017-06-03 15:10:36.000000000', 'message': "Add support for caching pkg_resources data

The cache file contains information both on packages and their versions

pbr.pkg_cache has a get_cache function that can be used by other

before they try reading from pkg_resources.

Change-Id: Id4edd373cc2546f1457596ba8a7ffa9176728823

commit_message:
Add support for caching pkg_resources data

Add two sub-commands to pbr:

  rebuild - scans pkg_resources info and writes a json cache file
  install -  runs pip install then rebuilds the cache file

Then, add support to the version fetching code to read from the cache
file if it's present.

The cache file contains information both on packages and their versions
as well as all of the entrypoints registered on the system.

pbr.pkg_cache has a get_cache function that can be used by other
things, such as potentially stevedore, to try reading from the cache
before they try reading from pkg_resources.

Change-Id: Id4edd373cc2546f1457596ba8a7ffa9176728823

subject: Convert '-' to '_' in ansible facts for interface names
messages:
[{'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-10 02:56:27.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2018-12-11 15:28:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-13 12:39:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Just a thought: An intermediate variable would make this a lot clearer.

api_interface_fact_name: "{{ 'ansible_' ~ api_interface | replace('-', '_') }}"

Then reference as:

{{ hostvars[host]['api_interface_fact_name'] }}'}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:18:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

It could not work.
'ansible.vars.hostvars.HostVarsVars object' has no attribute 'api_interface_fact_name'"}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:25:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> It could not work.
 > 'ansible.vars.hostvars.HostVarsVars object' has no attribute
 > 'api_interface_fact_name'

You would have to add the definition of api_interface_fact_name to group_vars/all.yml."}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:25:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:26:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > It could not work.
 > > 'ansible.vars.hostvars.HostVarsVars object' has no attribute
 > > 'api_interface_fact_name'
 > 
 > You would have to add the definition of api_interface_fact_name to
 > group_vars/all.yml.

api_interface_fact_name: "{{ 'ansible_' ~ api_interface | replace('-', '_') }}"'}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:29:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

['api_interface_fact_name'] is string.."}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:33:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Don't need single quote,i would change it."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:34:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> ['api_interface_fact_name'] is string..

Yes, but hostvars[host] is a dict. If you index the dict with the name of a variable, you get the value of that variable for the host:

hostvars[host]['api_interface_fact_name'] = 'ansible_eth0'

> Don't need single quote,i would change it.

You do need the quotes. You want to get the value of the variable for another host, not the current host."}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:36:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, I think I didn't write out the full expression, perhaps that it confusing.

{{ hostvars[host][hostvars[host]['api_interface_fact_name']]['ipv4']['address'] }}"}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:39:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

'api_interface_fact_name' parsed into 'api_interface_fact_name' in host vars, not 'ansible_eth0'"}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:40:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

It works without quotes'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:42:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> It works without quotes

It might look like it works, but it is not doing the right thing. If there are different interfaces on different hosts, it will not work correctly.'}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:44:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yes, should be.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-14 10:58:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I gave it a try, seems to work: http://paste.openstack.org/show/737291/'}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-19 12:33:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2018-12-19 13:01:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2018-12-19 13:26:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2019-03-12 11:16:17.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-06-12 06:55:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2019-06-12 07:16:19.000000000', 'content': 'Restored'}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2019-06-12 08:08:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2019-06-17 03:02:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 29100, 'date': '2020-02-19 17:15:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

I also had a related changeset (Ibe49eaf57992f0564d0e37cb7a7ffc891b2777c4) - I expanded on the approach to have a custom Jinja filter that handles this complexity. We already use the kolla_address filter for getting the IPv4/IPv6 address. This changeset introduces kolla_device for similarly retrieving the Linux device name. It also handles ':', which are valid characters to be in the interface names."}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2020-02-20 10:58:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> I also had a related changeset (Ibe49eaf57992f0564d0e37cb7a7ffc891b2777c4)
 > - I expanded on the approach to have a custom Jinja filter that
 > handles this complexity. We already use the kolla_address filter
 > for getting the IPv4/IPv6 address. This changeset introduces
 > kolla_device for similarly retrieving the Linux device name. It
 > also handles ':', which are valid characters to be in the interface
 > names.

good, upstream has been implemented.
https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/src/branch/master/kolla_ansible/kolla_address.py"}, {'account_id': 28367, 'date': '2020-02-20 10:59:09.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Convert '-' to '_' in ansible facts for interface names

Avoid not getting the network address when the network interface name
contains a minus sign. Because the minus sign is going to be converted
into an underscore here in ansible.

Change-Id: Iac447a5cfba9a04cf0478e23c238f0095ab88923
Signed-off-by: ZijianGuo <guozijn@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2020-02-18 20:20:51.000000000', 'message': 'Deprecate deployment of MongoDB

Per http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/kolla/2020/kolla.2020-02-12-15.01.txt

Deprecates support for deploying MongoDB. In Victoria support for
deploying MongoDB will be removed from Kolla Ansible. Note CentOS 8
already lost support for MongoDB due to decisions made upstream.

This affects Panko as it will no longer be possible to get automatic
deployment of MongoDB database for it. However, the default, SQL,
backend is and will be supported via MariaDB.

MongoDB lost its position in OpenStack environment after
controversial relicensing under their custom SSPL (Server Side
Public License) which did not pass OSI (Open Source Initiative)
validation.

Change-Id: I09f77d275dfd2c8f9ae97a47c8ab1136a8de880f
