commit_message:
Deprecate deployment of MongoDB

Per http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/kolla/2020/kolla.2020-02-12-15.01.txt

Deprecates support for deploying MongoDB. In Victoria support for
deploying MongoDB will be removed from Kolla Ansible. Note CentOS 8
already lost support for MongoDB due to decisions made upstream.

This affects Panko as it will no longer be possible to get automatic
deployment of MongoDB database for it. However, the default, SQL,
backend is and will be supported via MariaDB.

MongoDB lost its position in OpenStack environment after
controversial relicensing under their custom SSPL (Server Side
Public License) which did not pass OSI (Open Source Initiative)
validation.

Change-Id: I09f77d275dfd2c8f9ae97a47c8ab1136a8de880f

subject: Add VRRP failover test
messages: [{'account_id': 29350, 'date': '2020-02-20 10:25:08.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 29350, 'date': '2020-02-20 10:34:54.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nWrong repo'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-20 10:25:08.000000000', 'message': 'Add VRRP failover test

The aim of the test is to validate that in case master VM becomes not
available the traffic to the VIP is directed to the second VM.
Such setup is often used in setups with Octavia load balancers.

Scenario:
- Create a port for VRRP VIP and ports for VMs with
  allowed address pair configured to the VIP IP
- Create two VMs on different compute nodes
- Setup VRRP between the VMs
- Test traffic to virtual IP (login via ssh)
- Kill active VM
- Test traffic to virtual IP. Traffic should now flow to the second VM

Change-Id: Ib280ff6d8ae02ec7253437d88fa6bfee98a1c7bc
'}]
commit_message:
Add VRRP failover test

The aim of the test is to validate that in case master VM becomes not
available the traffic to the VIP is directed to the second VM.
Such setup is often used in setups with Octavia load balancers.

Scenario:
- Create a port for VRRP VIP and ports for VMs with
  allowed address pair configured to the VIP IP
- Create two VMs on different compute nodes
- Setup VRRP between the VMs
- Test traffic to virtual IP (login via ssh)
- Kill active VM
- Test traffic to virtual IP. Traffic should now flow to the second VM

Change-Id: Ib280ff6d8ae02ec7253437d88fa6bfee98a1c7bc

commit_message:
Drop support for tempest-full

Even after dropping support for py2, tempest-full job is still running
using python2.

Removed this job from the set of templates.

Change-Id: I4dd93511567ba180d758628ccd0307340ba74fe2

Not sure about the client side, but makes sense to handle this in the service. We have other places where we do the name to display_name conversion [0].

Though looking at the history, I think the intent was to migrate from display_name to name, so we should probably decide which one we want to use and start getting the steps in place to got to just one or the other. Or decide that both are always going to be valid and just make sure we always handle it.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/410791580ef60ddb03104bf20766859ed9d78932/cinder/api/v2/snapshots.py#L92'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2020-01-24 18:26:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

There was an effort in Pike to  generalize the resource filter code so that we didn't have to continue to have per-list-response (often duplicate) filter parameter processing, and that was connected to the v3 resource_filters API.  Looks like that effort didn't hit volume_transfers.  What I'm talking about are these changes:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/444598/
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/461668/

I'm mentioning them because it looks like we should have enough stuff in place here in cinder so that we can test to make sure that the filters named in the resource_filters response are respected by the API without having to locate these tests in the cinderclient.

So, to get to the point here, this code change looks OK; the -1 is for the commit message and also, I think, modifying etc/cinder/resource_filters.json to include the volume_transfers resource.  Although, as I noted in my comment on the commit message, I think that file has its problems, so maybe that should be a separate bug."}, {'account_id': 19755, 'date': '2020-01-26 10:21:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-01-21 17:30:32.000000000', 'message': "Correct volume transfer filters

In cinderclient, the default key is 'name'[1] but the database
column entry is 'display_name'.
To avoid this mismatch we change the filter key from 'name'
to 'display_name' (as also done for snapshot and backup listing).

The related functional tests are in cinderclient[2].

[1] https://github.com/openstack/python-cinderclient/blob/master/cinderclient/utils.py#L290
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/702951

Change-Id: I6a4d12d5dd55080e9aa73027ed82d3bf13855e28
Closes-Bug: #1860100
"}, {'created': '2020-01-29 08:09:50.000000000', 'message': 'Support volume transfer `name` filters

The `name` filter for volume transfer is not currently recognized by the
API.
This patch adds the support for it while secretly continuing to
support `display_name` as a valid filter.

Change-Id: I6a4d12d5dd55080e9aa73027ed82d3bf13855e28
Closes-Bug: #1860100
'}, {'created': '2020-01-29 08:49:25.000000000', 'message': 'Support volume transfer `name` filters

The `name` filter for volume transfer is not currently recognized by the
API.
This patch adds the support for it while secretly continuing to
support `display_name` as a valid filter.

Change-Id: I6a4d12d5dd55080e9aa73027ed82d3bf13855e28
Closes-Bug: #1860100
'}, {'created': '2020-02-07 06:51:26.000000000', 'message': "Support volume transfer `name` filters

The `name` filter for volume transfer is not currently recognized by the
API. Instead, it allowed filtering on 'display_name', which is not the
actual name of any attribute of the resource.
This patch adds the support for it while secretly continuing to
support `display_name` as a valid filter so as not to break people who
have figured out the workaround.

Change-Id: I6a4d12d5dd55080e9aa73027ed82d3bf13855e28
Closes-Bug: #1860100
"}]
commit_message:
Support volume transfer `name` filters

The `name` filter for volume transfer is not currently recognized by the
API. Instead, it allowed filtering on 'display_name', which is not the
actual name of any attribute of the resource.
This patch adds the support for it while secretly continuing to
support `display_name` as a valid filter so as not to break people who
have figured out the workaround.

Change-Id: I6a4d12d5dd55080e9aa73027ed82d3bf13855e28
Closes-Bug: #1860100

commit_message:
Deprecate XenAPI integrations

Per http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-February/012662.html
and http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-September/009180.html

Deprecates support for deploying with XenAPI integrations.
In Victoria support for these will be removed from Kolla Ansible.

This is dictated by lack of interest and maintenance, and upstream
decision of deprecation by Nova (for the same reasons).

Change-Id: Ie2bfc41dd7085f35e89a5c4e0b7fdb44631eb4e3

Deprecates support for deploying with VMware integrations.

commit_message:
Clean up some kolla-kubernetes cruft in OVS

The start-ovsdb-server script is only ever called with one argument by
kolla ansible, so we can remove the multiple argument handling used by
kolla-kubernetes (RIP).

Change-Id: I9c3bc8ad24768052fc883c6fedd5f19336eb3fa4

commit_message:
zuul: Add a devstack-platform-fedora-latest-virt-preview job

Building on I5c3e1b7b632fd73310c462530990cdb0e0c0ceea we can now add a
Fedora job using the virt-preview repo that will be used by Nova's
experimental queue.

Change-Id: Iad9d64912bb07f307e4897ece1621f275f1d5211

[{'created': '2020-02-14 10:41:55.000000000', 'message': 'Fix adhoc actions

* Method _create_action_execution() for AdHocActin didn't have
  the right signature. It was missing the argument "namespace" and
  failed under some conditions. In fact, this method is not needed
  at all because the value passed in ths parameter can never be
  different from its based action definition. So the method was
  simple removed and for this class the corresponding method
  from the super class is now used.
* Style changes (blank lines, formatting).

Change-Id: I84d1cd0fb4a746197ad890276f654cd12455603e

Change-Id: I84d1cd0fb4a746197ad890276f654cd12455603e
'}, {'created': '2020-02-19 06:13:13.000000000', 'message': 'Fix adhoc actions

* Method _create_action_execution() for AdHocActin didn't have
  the right signature. It was missing the argument "namespace" and
  failed under some conditions. This patch does some refactoring
  to preserve the target namespace during action init time. For
  regular python actions it's just taken from it's action definition
  object. For ad-hoc actions it is taken from its definition also
  but it has to do it separately because it extends the class
  PythonAction passing a base action definition into it as a parameter
  of the initializer (so that extracts the namespace of the base action).
  The benefit of preserving a namespace value during init time is that
  it becomes available for the entire instance life-span, not only for
  the method _create_action_execution().
* Style changes (blank lines, formatting).

Change-Id: I84d1cd0fb4a746197ad890276f654cd12455603e
'}, {'created': '2020-02-19 06:47:49.000000000', 'message': 'Fix adhoc actions

  failed under some conditions. This patch does some refactoring
  to preserve the target namespace during action init time. For
  regular python actions it's just taken from it's action definition
  object. For ad-hoc actions it is taken from its definition also
  but it has to do it separately because it extends the class
  PythonAction passing a base action definition into it as a parameter
  of the initializer (so that extracts the namespace of the base action).
  The benefit of preserving a namespace value during init time is that
  it becomes available for the entire instance life-span, not only for
  the method _create_action_execution().
* Style changes (blank lines, indentation, formatting).

Change-Id: I84d1cd0fb4a746197ad890276f654cd12455603e
'}]
commit_message:
Fix adhoc actions

* Method _create_action_execution() for AdHocActin didn't have
  the right signature. It was missing the argument "namespace" and
  failed under some conditions. This patch does some refactoring
  to preserve the target namespace during action init time. For
  regular python actions it's just taken from it's action definition
  object. For ad-hoc actions it is taken from its definition also
  but it has to do it separately because it extends the class
  PythonAction passing a base action definition into it as a parameter
  of the initializer (so that extracts the namespace of the base action).
  The benefit of preserving a namespace value during init time is that
  it becomes available for the entire instance life-span, not only for
  the method _create_action_execution().
* Style changes (blank lines, indentation, formatting).

Change-Id: I84d1cd0fb4a746197ad890276f654cd12455603e

MessageTimeout while waiting for VIF plugging again:

1) The error tends to happen during the policyd validation after the initial load balancer test. At this point in time we have already created one amphora loadbalancer which amounts to 4 VMs (1 active/backup pair and one spare pair) and one OVN load balancer.  The VMs used for compute do not have endless capacity, could this be a load/resource related issue?

2) The default value for `vif_plugging_timeout` is 300, but we're most likely hitting the default for `rpc_response_timeout` of 60 before that, is that a general problem we need to address?

commit_message:
Add Octavia OVN provider driver support

For use cases that do not require TLS termination or load balancing
based on higher layer characteristics, there is a Octavia OVN provider
driver that delegates load balancing to the network itself and does
not require VMs to handle the traffic.

Use the common ``parts/section-keystone-authtoken`` for keystone
auth in templates.

Change-Id: I1b9704c9e040eef821cef1e4f16faa0b18dce85e

messages:
[{'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2020-01-17 18:00:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2020-01-17 23:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2020-01-19 20:15:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

The root cause of last failure is missing handling of the ``SIGPIPE`` signal in Neutron.  Since Neutron is using threads for it workers any thread can get itself into a situation where the process would receive a SIGPIPE signal, not catching it will most likely cause unintended consequences for all threads running in that process.

The likelihood of this happening increases when using OVN as multiple Neutron processes are connected to the Northbound and Southbound OVSDB servers.

The ovsdb-server defaults to a quite aggressive policy on probing for and reaping inactive connections.

We may need to tape over this by increasing the inactivity_probe value for the ovsdb-server listeners, but I guess a proper fix would be catching that signal combined with proper ovsdb-server connection handling for OVN in Neutron.'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2020-01-24 11:59:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

commit_message:
Enable use of OVN for plumbing to octavia units

commit_message:
python-vitrageclient: do not run unit tests on RDO

One of the unit tests [1] is failing in RDO. Let's skip unit tests
for now, until we can find a better fix.

[1] - tests.cli.test_topology_show.TopologyShowTest.test_dot_emitter

Change-Id: I8aeff9e6ea1f56917687dc8544774b8cb3585b3c

commit_message:
Project Contributing updates for Goal

This change covers changes to meet the goal of establishing contributor
documentation, which Ironic largely already had, but required some
enhancement and clarification.

This also includes rough context of the PTL duties and revision to the
primary repository CONTRIBUTING document, as suggested in some of the
goal related discussions.

Change-Id: Ia47eb56d7eb3c19c99fa7a61fb5605037dd9ebee
Story: #2007236
Task: #38528

commit_message:
Update gpu driver

Current gpu driver is out of data, it cannot generate attribute info
("resource_class"/"rc" and "traits") of the gpu device, as a result
cyborg-conductor cannot report the device to placement and nova cannot
schedule this device during the process of nova boot.
This patch added the attribute_list generation in gpu driver so that
the device info can be reported to placement and user can boot an instance
with gpu device.

Change-Id: Ifd44d388d8982f90a3e1c5dd35116cae68e80627

commit_message:
Remove tarball artifact publishing to static site

Following-on from Ia3a0358249e9ed3d766b1b61535f2f6d67d4eb2d, this
removes the publishing from the static site, which is now happening to
AFS.

The site_tarballs secret is no longer required.  The two jobs still
using it have a parent of publish-openstack-artifacts so should not
need a separate secret.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/706732
Change-Id: I1b1db7d2451d7fb1fdd7921e7c9efd0e020fbce6

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

Masakari is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/
Change-Id: I144571286343e6be2518e3fe72e33c86a0fd0dfe

subject: tripleo_container_manage: disable logging for tasks using container_data
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-19 21:45:16.000000000', 'message': 'tripleo_container_manage: disable logging for tasks using container_data

container_data contains the config data for each container, which can be
passwords or other secrets. Ansible would show it in the logs when
executing the resources, which leaks sensitive data. Only enable that
display if tripleo_container_manage_debug is set to True; like we
already do for some other tasks.

Change-Id: I2d58a3a234b94d5b5d2cc16b47c9751f78a416d9
(cherry picked from commit 5b4b445ddea456851541357544b8cf19aca50e84)
'}]
commit_message:
tripleo_container_manage: disable logging for tasks using container_data

container_data contains the config data for each container, which can be
passwords or other secrets. Ansible would show it in the logs when
executing the resources, which leaks sensitive data. Only enable that
display if tripleo_container_manage_debug is set to True; like we
already do for some other tasks.

Change-Id: I2d58a3a234b94d5b5d2cc16b47c9751f78a416d9
(cherry picked from commit 5b4b445ddea456851541357544b8cf19aca50e84)

messages: [{'account_id': 16465, 'date': '2020-02-20 01:20:28.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-02-20 01:38:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-02-20 03:56:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nLack of cherry pick is fine since this is just a config change. revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-20 01:20:28.000000000', 'message': "Constraint dependencies for docs build

Without this patch, new library releases (even if not specifically
related to sphinx or docs) can break the docs build. For example, the
latest Werkzeug release is breaking the docs for the stable/stein branch
due to an import error that was fixed in later branches. We shouldn't be
letting new library releases affect the docs environment for the same
reason we want to control the other tox environments. This change adds
-c to the docs tox environment so ensure that all libraries installed in
this environment are known good versions.

Manual port of 13410383cf55699f756c6ce01301d7e67c65b575 edited to
reference train instead of master.

Change-Id: I987918023525ff165ada691feda23ee86c7e36de
"}]
commit_message:
Constraint dependencies for docs build

Without this patch, new library releases (even if not specifically
related to sphinx or docs) can break the docs build. For example, the
latest Werkzeug release is breaking the docs for the stable/stein branch
due to an import error that was fixed in later branches. We shouldn't be
letting new library releases affect the docs environment for the same
reason we want to control the other tox environments. This change adds
-c to the docs tox environment so ensure that all libraries installed in
this environment are known good versions.

Manual port of 13410383cf55699f756c6ce01301d7e67c65b575 edited to
reference train instead of master.

Change-Id: I987918023525ff165ada691feda23ee86c7e36de

commit_message:
Fixed define incorrectly of the exc msg

The exception used here is actually defined incorrectly, having a
message class variable instead of _msg_fmt, which caused it to not
render properly.

Change-Id: I4f2ec8b2216f6cb89104a25aad633b9109beb347

commit_message:
v2 API Support(using openstack-sdk)

Modifying cyborgclient to supporting v2 API,
and using openstack sdk.
This patch depends openstacksdk patch[1].

command usage:
$openstack accelerator *commands below*

deployable ( list | show | program )
device list
device profile ( list | create | delete | show )
arq ( list | create | delete | show | bind | unbind )

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/679914/

Change-Id: If6bb52b453c1aa7fb328fd08ebbb79312fa7d299
Story: 2006930

subject: Fix some minor concept and typo
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-18 12:10:18.000000000', 'message': 'Fix some minor concept and typo

This patch first use system instead of global.

The system scope are not equal global scope. They
have different meanings reference to the definition
of keystone[1].

And this patch also fix some typo.

Reference:
[1]. http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/queens/system-scope.html

Change-Id: I727a451602ad44248a9532e5c3e688b44ae8a722
'}]
commit_message:
Fix some minor concept and typo

This patch first use system instead of global.

The system scope are not equal global scope. They
have different meanings reference to the definition
of keystone[1].

And this patch also fix some typo.

Reference:
[1]. http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/specs/keystone/queens/system-scope.html

Change-Id: I727a451602ad44248a9532e5c3e688b44ae8a722

[{'created': '2020-02-12 23:24:08.000000000', 'message': "Tell reno to ignore the kilo branch

When reno 3.x runs under setuptools, it scans all of the branches it can
find, including any that look like they're closed and have an -eol tag.
The old kilo branch in this repository has a jumbled history that
somehow makes it look like it should include tags that it doesn't. We
know that there are no release notes in that branch, because reno wasn't
adopted while it was open. The releasenotes/source/index.rst links to
separate release notes in the wiki.

This patch tells reno to ignore that branch so that it doesn't throw an
exception when it gets confused about the old tag.

Change-Id: Idd56c3f37d5786daae7181c36d38d267cbf1885c
Co-Authored-By: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 94b228464dd0c1594c974d333cd31519a48d3761)
"}]
commit_message:
Tell reno to ignore the kilo branch

When reno 3.x runs under setuptools, it scans all of the branches it can
find, including any that look like they're closed and have an -eol tag.
The old kilo branch in this repository has a jumbled history that
somehow makes it look like it should include tags that it doesn't. We
know that there are no release notes in that branch, because reno wasn't
adopted while it was open. The releasenotes/source/index.rst links to
separate release notes in the wiki.

This patch tells reno to ignore that branch so that it doesn't throw an
exception when it gets confused about the old tag.

Change-Id: Idd56c3f37d5786daae7181c36d38d267cbf1885c
Co-Authored-By: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 94b228464dd0c1594c974d333cd31519a48d3761)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-19 20:11:58.000000000', 'message': 'tripleo_container_manage: disable logging for tasks using container_data

container_data contains the config data for each container, which can be
passwords or other secrets. Ansible would show it in the logs when
executing the resources, which leaks sensitive data. Only enable that
display if tripleo_container_manage_debug is set to True; like we
already do for some other tasks.

Change-Id: I2d58a3a234b94d5b5d2cc16b47c9751f78a416d9
'}]
commit_message:
tripleo_container_manage: disable logging for tasks using container_data

container_data contains the config data for each container, which can be
passwords or other secrets. Ansible would show it in the logs when
executing the resources, which leaks sensitive data. Only enable that
display if tripleo_container_manage_debug is set to True; like we
already do for some other tasks.

Change-Id: I2d58a3a234b94d5b5d2cc16b47c9751f78a416d9

commit_message:
Set PROFILE_TASKS_TASK_OUTPUT_LIMIT

Currently it is set to 0 by default which results in a summary not
being printed at the end of the ansible playbook run. It would
greatly benefit operators if we printed out the top 50 time consuming
tasks at the end of the playbook run.

Change-Id: I140fe66091d4e7a710f04da15cc93b7e6bf5742c
Signed-off-by: Sai Sindhur Malleni <smalleni@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2020-02-04 12:44:03.000000000', 'message': 'Swap tasks to avoid non-existing variable error.

The upgrade workflow to Stein has a guard task that
checks that the --limit option is being used when
running the overcloud upgrade run command, as the
upgrade needs to be performed node by node due to
the operating system upgrade. However, if the --limit
option is not passed, the upgrade tasks fails in the
task right before the guard, as that task already

Change-Id: I9ffddcaa52314c615362969757c94ebdf01a3b6d
Closes-Bug: #1861663
(cherry picked from commit bca35e611bbc8f103e4893282c9b2c49aa4e1e48)

commit_message:
Swap tasks to avoid non-existing variable error.

The upgrade workflow to Stein has a guard task that
checks that the --limit option is being used when
running the overcloud upgrade run command, as the
upgrade needs to be performed node by node due to
the operating system upgrade. However, if the --limit
option is not passed, the upgrade tasks fails in the
task right before the guard, as that task already
references the undefined variable. So, it is needed
to invert the order so we fail at will in the guard
task.

Change-Id: I9ffddcaa52314c615362969757c94ebdf01a3b6d
Closes-Bug: #1861663
(cherry picked from commit bca35e611bbc8f103e4893282c9b2c49aa4e1e48)

commit_message:
Constraint dependencies for docs build

Without this patch, new library releases (even if not specifically
related to sphinx or docs) can break the docs build. For example, the
latest Werkzeug release is breaking the docs for the stable/stein branch
due to an import error that was fixed in later branches. We shouldn't be
letting new library releases affect the docs environment for the same
reason we want to control the other tox environments. This change adds
-c to the docs tox environment so ensure that all libraries installed in
this environment are known good versions.

Change-Id: I7cec5478bd276594485ed3ce434ba8dda1975ce4
(cherry picked from commit 13410383cf55699f756c6ce01301d7e67c65b575)

commit_message:
Constraint dependencies for docs build

Without this patch, new library releases (even if not specifically
related to sphinx or docs) can break the docs build. For example, the
latest Werkzeug release is breaking the docs for the stable/stein branch
due to an import error that was fixed in later branches. We shouldn't be
letting new library releases affect the docs environment for the same
reason we want to control the other tox environments. This change adds
-c to the docs tox environment so ensure that all libraries installed in
this environment are known good versions.

Change-Id: I7cec5478bd276594485ed3ce434ba8dda1975ce4
(cherry picked from commit 13410383cf55699f756c6ce01301d7e67c65b575)

commit_message:
Constraint dependencies for docs build

Without this patch, new library releases (even if not specifically
related to sphinx or docs) can break the docs build. For example, the
latest Werkzeug release is breaking the docs for the stable/stein branch
due to an import error that was fixed in later branches. We shouldn't be
letting new library releases affect the docs environment for the same
reason we want to control the other tox environments. This change adds
-c to the docs tox environment so ensure that all libraries installed in
this environment are known good versions.

Change-Id: I7cec5478bd276594485ed3ce434ba8dda1975ce4

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-10 13:25:12.000000000', 'message': '[OVN] Devstack: Fix adding another compute node

In order to add another compute node to an existing DevStack setup
(multi-node) we need to set a few extra variables to the local.conf to
enable the OVN driver in neutron.

The patch is also adding a new neutron_plugin_create_nova_conf function
to the ovn_agent module (no-op) otherwise the DevStack setup will fail.

Change-Id: I4d53f7206f151dc7ffa51b4c8bd601279aa88a46
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
[OVN] Devstack: Fix adding another compute node

In order to add another compute node to an existing DevStack setup
(multi-node) we need to set a few extra variables to the local.conf to
enable the OVN driver in neutron.

The patch is also adding a new neutron_plugin_create_nova_conf function
to the ovn_agent module (no-op) otherwise the DevStack setup will fail.

Change-Id: I4d53f7206f151dc7ffa51b4c8bd601279aa88a46
Signed-off-by: Lucas Alvares Gomes <lucasagomes@gmail.com>

Disable paunch on fs050

... So we can test upgrades between containerized undercloud with Paunch
to a deployment without Paunch.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/708241/

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-19 11:28:53.000000000', 'message': 'tripleo_container_manage: set tripleo_container_manage_check_puppet_config

Setting tripleo_container_manage_check_puppet_config to true will allow
us to get up-to-date config hashes in the container startup config right
before we decide if a container needs to be restarted or not.
It helps to have idempotent ansible runs and we avoid the restart of
containers when not needed.

Change-Id: I88b29a13d8e7c149f52e41d9fe8aa1f5dda2ecd9
(cherry picked from commit ddb47c23a66f4eee61343fd69ba20e3230fb3c77)
'}]
commit_message:
tripleo_container_manage: set tripleo_container_manage_check_puppet_config

Setting tripleo_container_manage_check_puppet_config to true will allow
us to get up-to-date config hashes in the container startup config right
before we decide if a container needs to be restarted or not.
It helps to have idempotent ansible runs and we avoid the restart of
containers when not needed.

Change-Id: I88b29a13d8e7c149f52e41d9fe8aa1f5dda2ecd9
(cherry picked from commit ddb47c23a66f4eee61343fd69ba20e3230fb3c77)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-19 11:58:48.000000000', 'message': "Add swiftoperator role on ceph-rgw template

When deploying an Overcloud with Swift a role named
swiftoperator is created.
This change make sure we have swiftoperator role
when Ceph Object Gateway is created as well (as it's
replacement for swift).

Change-Id: I86c7ff98005d9ca79234854e4071e5b15ece9f6e
(cherry picked from commit f0aaaed685107e4acc1d30f2c1d0dafeb21fc88f)
"}]
commit_message:
Add swiftoperator role on ceph-rgw template

When deploying an Overcloud with Swift a role named
swiftoperator is created.
This change make sure we have swiftoperator role
when Ceph Object Gateway is created as well (as it's
replacement for swift).

Change-Id: I86c7ff98005d9ca79234854e4071e5b15ece9f6e
(cherry picked from commit f0aaaed685107e4acc1d30f2c1d0dafeb21fc88f)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-07 20:37:54.000000000', 'message': "Seagate driver: Add Basic auth header when logging in via HTTPS

New array firmware will use a new authentication method that does not
rely on MD5. To support this change while maintaining full backwards
compatibility, we'll also send a Basic auth header iff the connection
is encrypted.

Change-Id: I6d41f983992a47fb10fdb557dbbf7e3bbcc94b2e
"}]
commit_message:
Seagate driver: Add Basic auth header when logging in via HTTPS

New array firmware will use a new authentication method that does not
rely on MD5. To support this change while maintaining full backwards
compatibility, we'll also send a Basic auth header iff the connection
is encrypted.

Change-Id: I6d41f983992a47fb10fdb557dbbf7e3bbcc94b2e

in the API. Users can send --all-projects via OSC

commit_message:
OSC Fix list for all projects

The manila api accepts all_tenants as a parametes
in the API. Users can send --all-projects via OSC
and the client translates to all_tenants.

Change-Id: I5f9e685659160e676e70281e8f258a19b6133bfa
Partially-implements: bp openstack-client-support
Signed-off-by: Spyros Trigazis <spyridon.trigazis@cern.ch>

commit_message:
Deprecate 'accessIPv4'/'accessIPv6' attributes

Nova now return these two attributes with empty value,
deprecated them.

Change-Id: Id176d8cbc332cb02ff4f1523993ee5b232e0aa15

commit_message:
Remove the [pxe]ipxe_enabled configuration option

The ipxe_enabled configuration option was deprecated for quite a while,
this patch removes it. However the code impact by simply removing the
configuration option is quite large, so the strategy here is to register
the option dynamically but sticks to False, which essentially disabled
the ipxe support in the pxe interface.

Story: 2007003
Task: 37779

Change-Id: I499e627f780b577e351fd39be5fa93a34d384e64

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-18 10:09:02.000000000', 'message': 'Add pywinrm to global-requirements.txt

The "oswin-tempest-plugin" is using the pywinrm library, yet it's
not included in the global-requirements.txt file.

Although not set as as a hard dependency, the Manila Windows driver
(similar to the generic Linux driver but using Windows instances)
is also using pywinrm.

pywinrm allows sending commands to remote Windows hosts via WinRM,
pretty much resembling SSH.

Change-Id: I57f958ca93a2dd424ce988cd28816550bbd6e2d9
Closes-Bug: #1745823
'}, {'created': '2020-02-18 12:09:24.000000000', 'message': 'Add pywinrm to global-requirements.txt

The "oswin-tempest-plugin" is using the pywinrm library, yet it's
not included in the global-requirements.txt file.

Although not set as as a hard dependency, the Manila Windows driver
(similar to the generic Linux driver but using Windows instances)
is also using pywinrm.

pywinrm allows sending commands to remote Windows hosts via WinRM,
pretty much resembling SSH.

Change-Id: I57f958ca93a2dd424ce988cd28816550bbd6e2d9
Closes-Bug: #1745823
'}, {'created': '2020-02-18 13:34:30.000000000', 'message': "Add pywinrm to global-requirements.txt

pywinrm allows sending commands to remote Windows hosts via WinRM,
pretty much resembling SSH.

- Is the library actively maintained?

Yes, there are a few quite recent releases:
https://github.com/diyan/pywinrm/releases

- Is the library good code?

Yes. Despite being pre-1.0, it provides a stable and well documented API. The
code is easy to understand and well tested. It's a simple library that
implements the WinRM SOAP protocol.

- Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

- Is the library license compatible?

Yes, it's MIT licensed.

- Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest /
Fedora latest)?

Yes, it's available on PyPI as well as Ubuntu upstream repositories.

- Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
global-requirements.txt?

No.

- Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes, it's already used by the Manila Windows driver (similar to the Linux
generic one but using Windows instances) as well as the oswin-tempest-plugin
project.

- If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process does
it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

No, it's not an openstack project.

- Do I need to update anything else?

No.

Change-Id: I57f958ca93a2dd424ce988cd28816550bbd6e2d9
Closes-Bug: #1745823
"}]
commit_message:
Add pywinrm to global-requirements.txt

pywinrm allows sending commands to remote Windows hosts via WinRM,
pretty much resembling SSH.

- Is the library actively maintained?

Yes, there are a few quite recent releases:
https://github.com/diyan/pywinrm/releases

- Is the library good code?

Yes. Despite being pre-1.0, it provides a stable and well documented API. The
code is easy to understand and well tested. It's a simple library that
implements the WinRM SOAP protocol.

- Is the library python 3 compatible?

Yes.

- Is the library license compatible?

Yes, it's MIT licensed.

- Is the library already packaged in the distros we target (Ubuntu latest /
Fedora latest)?

Yes, it's available on PyPI as well as Ubuntu upstream repositories.

- Is the function of this library already covered by other libraries in
global-requirements.txt?

No.

- Is the library required for OpenStack project or related dev or
infrastructure setup? (Answer to this should be Yes, of course) Which?

Yes, it's already used by the Manila Windows driver (similar to the Linux
generic one but using Windows instances) as well as the oswin-tempest-plugin
project.

- If the library release is managed by the Openstack release process does
it use the cycle-with-intermediary release type?

No, it's not an openstack project.

- Do I need to update anything else?

No.

Change-Id: I57f958ca93a2dd424ce988cd28816550bbd6e2d9
Closes-Bug: #1745823

commit_message:
Check SG members instead of ports to skip flow update

Security group can have a state of empty ports but non-empty members. So
we need skip the flow update only when members dict is empty.

Change-Id: I429edb3d2dea5fa97441909b4d2c776f97f0516f
Closes-Bug: #1862703
Related-Bug: #1854131
(cherry picked from commit 6dbba8d5ce18805a6f104782510c055017267435)

commit_message:
Check SG members instead of ports to skip flow update

Security group can have a state of empty ports but non-empty members. So
we need skip the flow update only when members dict is empty.

Change-Id: I429edb3d2dea5fa97441909b4d2c776f97f0516f
Closes-Bug: #1862703
Related-Bug: #1854131
(cherry picked from commit 6dbba8d5ce18805a6f104782510c055017267435)

commit_message:
Check SG members instead of ports to skip flow update

Security group can have a state of empty ports but non-empty members. So
we need skip the flow update only when members dict is empty.

Change-Id: I429edb3d2dea5fa97441909b4d2c776f97f0516f
Closes-Bug: #1862703
Related-Bug: #1854131
(cherry picked from commit 6dbba8d5ce18805a6f104782510c055017267435)

Support the new option in Paunch which allows to not cleaning containers
not part of a config.

Also by security, if only one .json file is given in "config" parameter,
we will force cleanup to false, to avoid the deletion of the other

Change-Id: Ib9115be94b704072393c3c510e6158baddab2dc6
(cherry picked from commit fa6514b6f7b68f8508b9960fa9a38a39f4d99e0a)

commit_message:
paunch: add "cleanup" parameter, useful for apply action

Support the new option in Paunch which allows to not cleaning containers
not part of a config.

Also by security, if only one .json file is given in "config" parameter,
we will force cleanup to false, to avoid the deletion of the other
containers in the same config id.

Change-Id: Ib9115be94b704072393c3c510e6158baddab2dc6
(cherry picked from commit fa6514b6f7b68f8508b9960fa9a38a39f4d99e0a)

configuration, so move it to the block reserved for healhtcheck tasks so

(cherry picked from commit bd48b3cb157d90e71a5306f4834347ab201329a8)

commit_message:
podman/systemd: fix task indentation for timer

The timer task needs to be skipped if there is no healthcheck in the
configuration, so move it to the block reserved for healhtcheck tasks so
it gets ignored when a container has no healthecheck.

Change-Id: Ie1a4c5af7c2e8ff3e6ff0b85f264239a8e30e913
(cherry picked from commit bd48b3cb157d90e71a5306f4834347ab201329a8)

commit_message:
Make filter_kwargs check before adding postfix

Ensure we aren't appending the '_id' postfix if the key
already has it, thus resulting in a key of '*_id_id'

Change-Id: I158688bbd49110c3a169a42b8ecadfd313c623cb
Closes-Bug: 1742800

Otherwise LGTM."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-11-20 01:09:46.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-11-20 01:19:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-11-20 02:07:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

RECHECK'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-11-20 06:09:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2017-12-01 14:01:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

This fixes it in the backend but what about at the user facing layer? http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/resource/schema.py#n19

I wonder if it counts as an API break if a 65-character project name starts giving 200s instead of 404s...'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-12-04 02:45:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-12-04 03:31:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

I think the migration action should be in expand, not contract.
Here is the reason:
contract should be run after all nodes are in the new release. So If you add the migration script in contract, it means that before running contract, Keystone will allow the name be 255, but the db is still limit 64.
If run the migration in expand. It means that during migration, the db is limit 255. The new release(255) and the old release(64) can both work. 
Maybe it's footy, but we should take care. Correct me if I'm wrong. Thanks."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-12-04 03:52:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> This fixes it in the backend but what about at the user facing
 > layer? http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/keystone/tree/keystone/resource/schema.py#n19
Ty! Changed now. Although I find it weird that identity/schema.py leaves the name max length to the backend, but resource/schema.py doesn't. Seems a little inconsistent. 

 > I wonder if it counts as an API break if a 65-character project
 > name starts giving 200s instead of 404s...

I'm conflicted about this. :/

Nothing is really breaking or changing, only that if someone really heavily relied on short project names and was leaving the enforcing to Keystone, then maybe, but the likelihood of that is low. I'm more willing to bet most people don't even think about the length of project names at all.

The real worry is some other service or tool that stores project names (rather than ids, or along with ids), and it has the name max length as 64 characters in their db, but there is no easy way to check that, nor do I know any services that do that. If such a service encountered a >64 character project name, then it will break, but that's in part why we use IDs normally everywhere, since they aren't a variable length and have a set format/type of content. I'd hope no one is silly enough to do that though and uses only IDs. Then again if this does crop up, it an easy fix that probably needed to happen anyway in their service/code.

That said it looks stupid in Horizon, but it does work. Most people will still have <64 character names, but having the option to have them longer is nice for the weird use cases like mine."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-12-04 04:16:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

> I think the migration action should be in expand, not contract.
 > Here is the reason:
 > contract should be run after all nodes are in the new release. So
 > If you add the migration script in contract, it means that before
 > running contract, Keystone will allow the name be 255, but the db
 > is still limit 64.
 > If run the migration in expand. It means that during migration, the
 > db is limit 255. The new release(255) and the old release(64) can
 > both work.
 > Maybe it's footy, but we should take care. Correct me if I'm wrong.
 > Thanks.

I'm going by what the migrations guidelines state:
'Expand phase: Only additive schema changes are allowed, such as new columns, tables, indices, and triggers.'
So no alters.

You're right though, newer code would be running, and you could attempt to create a new project with a longer name, and you'd get a 500. Nothing beyond that would break though, but you would get a 500 rather than a 400 or a 200, which isn't that terrible since no data would actually get inserted, just not great ux.

Having the name max length be 255 on the backend while the older code is running actually wouldn't break, so there could be an argument for this being in expand since it's a non-destructive alter."}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-12-04 04:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-12-04 04:26:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 15054, 'date': '2017-12-04 06:30:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> > I think the migration action should be in expand, not contract.
 > > Here is the reason:
 > > contract should be run after all nodes are in the new release. So
 > > If you add the migration script in contract, it means that before
 > > running contract, Keystone will allow the name be 255, but the db
 > > is still limit 64.
 > > If run the migration in expand. It means that during migration,
 > the
 > > db is limit 255. The new release(255) and the old release(64) can
 > > both work.
 > > Maybe it's footy, but we should take care. Correct me if I'm
 > wrong.
 > > Thanks.
 > 
 > I'm going by what the migrations guidelines state:
 > 'Expand phase: Only additive schema changes are allowed, such as
 > new columns, tables, indices, and triggers.'
 > So no alters.
 > 
 > You're right though, newer code would be running, and you could
 > attempt to create a new project with a longer name, and you'd get a
 > 500. Nothing beyond that would break though, but you would get a
 > 500 rather than a 400 or a 200, which isn't that terrible since no
 > data would actually get inserted, just not great ux.
 > 
 > Having the name max length be 255 on the backend while the older
 > code is running actually wouldn't break, so there could be an
 > argument for this being in expand since it's a non-destructive
 > alter.

following the database migrations guide, you are right. But I'm not sure the guide is correct in this case. Just leave my thought here."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2017-12-04 09:11:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> Nothing is really breaking or changing, only that if someone really heavily relied on short project names and was leaving the enforcing to Keystone, then maybe, but the likelihood of that is low. I'm more willing to bet most people don't even think about the length of project names at all.

I would also be pretty surprised if anyone deeply cared about it, but it's actually being enforced by tempest which makes me think it counts as a semi-serious API change :/

 tempest.api.identity.admin.v3.test_domains_negative.DomainsNegativeTestJSON.test_create_domain_with_name_length_over_64[id-37b1bbf2-d664-4785-9a11-333438586eae,negative]

The example you gave of an external tool depending on the max character length seems like a real example of someone depending on the API emitting a 404 instead of a 200.

> Most people will still have <64 character names, but having the option to have them longer is nice for the weird use cases like mine.

Out of curiosity, what is your use case? What do you need such a long project name for?"}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2017-12-04 09:14:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> So If you add the migration script in contract, it means that before running contract, Keystone will allow the name be 255, but the db is still limit 64.

That's a good point, with this now including the schema change this would be broken. We might need to alter our sqlalchemy tests to allow this though."}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2017-12-04 16:48:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> > Nothing is really breaking or changing, only that if someone
 > really heavily relied on short project names and was leaving the
 > enforcing to Keystone, then maybe, but the likelihood of that is
 > low. I'm more willing to bet most people don't even think about the
 > length of project names at all.
 > 
 > I would also be pretty surprised if anyone deeply cared about it,
 > but it's actually being enforced by tempest which makes me think it
 > counts as a semi-serious API change :/
 > 
 > tempest.api.identity.admin.v3.test_domains_negative.DomainsNegativeTestJSON.test_create_domain_with_name_length_over_64[id-37b1bbf2-d664-4785-9a11-333438586eae,negative]
 > 
 > The example you gave of an external tool depending on the max
 > character length seems like a real example of someone depending on
 > the API emitting a 404 instead of a 200.
 > 
 > > Most people will still have <64 character names, but having the
 > option to have them longer is nice for the weird use cases like
 > mine.
 > 
 > Out of curiosity, what is your use case? What do you need such a
 > long project name for?

I think they want to store the hierarchy of the project as the name (e.g. /project-a/project-b/project-d)"}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2017-12-04 17:16:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review-2

This breaks the API contract by changing the behavior. We cannot change the behavior in this way without microversions (or a new major API). 

The reason for the -2, beyond the pedantic "this changes API behavior, is that it could impact real deployments in the following ways:

* If someone has a custom set of backends for resource or Identity, they may not handle > 64 Characters.

* If someone is relying on the name fields for CRM (or similar) integrations, this may explode beyond the allowable field sizes and cause these integerations to fail.

There are other reasons, I am sure, but those two were the first to come to mind.

If the PTL and other cores deem my -2 as inappropriate, I am happy to reverse to a no-score.'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2017-12-04 17:19:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

In addition, while we do not guarantee backend compatibility (aka column size consistentcy) this would need to be done in the following ways to get past the "rolling upgrades"

1) Add new correct name column (expand phase) with code that can read from both (and/or write to both... but truncate?)

2) Migrate from old to new (migrate phase)

3) contract phase: drop old column


Changing the column size would break anyone who is trying to roll the upgrade because of extra data coming from the DB schema where the objects do not know how to handle it.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-12-04 19:57:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

> This breaks the API contract by changing the behavior. We cannot
 > change the behavior in this way without microversions (or a new
 > major API).
 > 
 > The reason for the -2, beyond the pedantic "this changes API
 > behavior, is that it could impact real deployments in the following
 > ways:
 > 
 > * If someone has a custom set of backends for resource or Identity,
 > they may not handle > 64 Characters.
 > 
 > * If someone is relying on the name fields for CRM (or similar)
 > integrations, this may explode beyond the allowable field sizes and
 > cause these integerations to fail.
 > 
 > There are other reasons, I am sure, but those two were the first to
 > come to mind.
 > 
 > If the PTL and other cores deem my -2 as inappropriate, I am happy
 > to reverse to a no-score.

Can we do it with a microversion?

Or potentially do it so that the ability to turn on the extended project name length is configurable in some sense by the deployer? Sure that will mean more code, but it also means that we can migrate everything to 255, and only when the config is changed to allow it will data go in as 1-255. This also solves the rolling upgrades problem since you just don't turn the config setting on until ALL nodes are running new code.'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2017-12-04 20:30:33.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

and yes, the reason I need this is because I want to use the name as the project path down the tree. This lets me enforce namespaces and project name uniqueness down a tree.

This was talked about ages ago on the mailing list (my response on page 2):
https://openstack.nimeyo.com/97562/openstack-dev-keystone-project-name-db-length

Basically, all the attempts to solve namespace issues just don't work unless you treat the name as a path. And we ruled that out as impossible because it broke the API far too much, so I'd have to wait for v4 for us to fix that because nothing else really solves it (not even nested domain really, although it helps).

I talked about that in the above mail thread, and my favorite solution was, although I would have to wait until v4: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/318605/

So, as a compromise, since we can't make the API support unique name spaces down a tree of projects without breaking everyone, We've found a solution since we manage project creation at layer outside of Keystone first. We can enforce this path naming, which will enforce uniqueness across the domain. And even if the names gets too long to deal with, we can write some extra logic in horizon to shorten the names by splitting at '\'.

With 64 characters, we're surprisingly limited in how deep the trees can go. For now we'll be limiting 20 characters max per name, and warning our users about the max length, so if they plan well (with shorter names) they can do deeper, but I'd prefer to get around that limitation with a longer name at 255 eventually. Partly because I'm kind of expecting other deployers to be interested in the solution we've come up with so having that potentially longer name will benefit them too.

So, while this name length isn't a big deal now, I'd like to do it if we can, and others may hit it same I we are later. If it breaks the API too much, or we can't find something around that I'll live with it, but I'd much prefer if we can. 64 characters is fairly short compared to the name fields for other models in Keystone, and other projects (Nova server names are 255), so changing it is getting rid of a kind of odd and minor technical debt."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2017-12-04 21:32:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> Can we do it with a microversion?

Keystone doesn't do microversions currently

> Or potentially do it so that the ability to turn on the extended project name length is configurable in some sense by the deployer?

This would be counteractive to our interoperability goals."}, {'account_id': 8482, 'date': '2017-12-05 21:43:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Another thing about "what if microversions?" is, if we did change it in a microversion, what happens when a deployment upgrades, hasn't updated their backend to support >64 character names, and a user uses the microversion to try to create a project with a long name? We didn't officially break anything by any versioning rules but the backend wasn't prepared for it and would break.

Or supposing we put this in big red letters in the release notes and the deployer was prepared for it, what happens if a user uses the microversion to create a project and then makes a non-microversion request to retrieve it? The name would have to be truncated.

(mostly writing this down to add it to our "why keystone doesn't need microversions" arsenal)

But back to trying to solve the problem - could we add a new indexable longer column for this? We have the extras column which could hold this information but as far as I know it's not really searchable so not useful to a user trying to look up their own project. Or maybe there's some way we could manipulate project tags for this?'}, {'account_id': 2903, 'date': '2020-01-28 17:18:34.000000000', 'content': 'Removed reviewer Morgan Fainberg with the following votes:

* Code-Review-2 by Morgan Fainberg <morgan.fainberg@gmail.com>
'}, {'account_id': 10420, 'date': '2020-02-19 22:49:35.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
Add region parameters for keystone authentication

Add region_name parameters for keystone authentication in authtoken
middlleware and ceilometer middleware, so that we can specify the
keystone region where we expect keystone resources like swift user
are created.

Change-Id: I977ebb769eb79c715e0b19e97b9087bcbf578809

commit_message:
CEPH: upgrade ceph version from 14.2.5 to 14.2.7

This is to upgrade ceph version from 14.2.5 from 14.2.7  and also
to update ceph provisioners to use latest code from quay.io

  - rbd-provisioner: quay.io/external_storage/rbd-provisioner:v2.1.1-k8s1.11
  - cephfs-provisioner: quay.io/external_storage/cephfs-provisioner:v2.1.0-k8s1.11

This also updates verbs for proivioner's clusterrole to support new code.

Change-Id: Ia94129574610bb5c800a6941804e58ca3aefce65

commit_message:
Add support for ceph_external_multi_config

Add new parameter which may be used to trigger
additional runs of ceph-ansible where each additional
run uses extra_vars from each key in the new
parameter to configure the overcloud to use more
than one external Ceph cluster. Supported only
for the ceph-ansible client role.

Change-Id: I4fd47445f012878e595649be8371ea212548cbd8
Related-Bug: #1861488
(cherry picked from commit 23dbb5fedc2fb550d02d20589bf0f23f0a44063e)

commit_message:
[stable only] Use service_name in heira for firewall rules

We look for tripleo::${service_name}::firewall_rules hiera when
configuring firewall for services using puppet.

Change-Id: I552449dcae725f84d9c131cb97a5c1ad168b8661
Related-Bug: #1858096
(cherry picked from commit a9c6cd058fc30c621e56049924719dba17cf0863)

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-10-15 21:38:16.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2019-10-15 21:38:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

Sorry it's taken us so long to review this!"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-02-18 16:57:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 13852, 'date': '2020-02-18 18:39:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

I find the current behavior quite useful.

As an example, we deploy servers with unused harddrive on urpose. They are spare harddrives. When a disk is failing, we can immediatly provide a disk replacement by just updating the ring.

The fact that the process is running make this operation very easy. Also, it allows us to not have special cases for monitoring (the process must be running, no matter what).

I'd prefer to keep the current behavior. What harm does it cause?"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2020-02-19 18:29:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

recheck

IDK -- seems like it'd be nice to catch what could pretty easily be a misconfigured state. Should probably at least log a warning... maybe also add a config value like start_with_no_devices? Could have it take three values:

* false, refuse to start and print an error
* warn, print a warning but continue running the server (default)
* true, continue with old behavior

maybe with a note to deprecate warn, and we remove it in a cycle or two?  WDYT?"}]

commit_message:
prevent object-server from start if no devices

If there is no entry (this node's IP and port) in object ring,
object-server gets empty list of ports, and it causes
object-server doesn't bind any port but it's running without any
warning message in swift logs.

This patch is to prevent object-server from start if no devices
on this node.

Change-Id: Iffb6786da2a40ac23c37a8411a0064bfee96e801
Closes-bug: #1636228

subject: Always convert to docker media format
messages: [{'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-02-18 23:13:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-02-19 14:44:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-18 23:13:03.000000000', 'message': "Always convert to docker media format

Previously if the container config mediaType was unset or set to
something other than a docker format, we would just pass that on. This
caused problem with stricter checking of the metadata performed by some
versions of Podman. Since we're always converting the layer metadata
information to docker, we should ensure that the config media type is
properly set to a valid docker distribution format. This change ensure
that when we push the image config, that the mediaType is set to match
the contents type.

Change-Id: I6b6a8231f6881fdb53084a437ee24fd852ebdd55
Closes-Bug: #186585
(cherry picked from commit e7d1e59283e13da0d6a253df0a29a243444ed58e)
"}]
commit_message:
Always convert to docker media format

Previously if the container config mediaType was unset or set to
something other than a docker format, we would just pass that on. This
caused problem with stricter checking of the metadata performed by some
versions of Podman. Since we're always converting the layer metadata
information to docker, we should ensure that the config media type is
properly set to a valid docker distribution format. This change ensure
that when we push the image config, that the mediaType is set to match
the contents type.

Change-Id: I6b6a8231f6881fdb53084a437ee24fd852ebdd55
Closes-Bug: #186585
(cherry picked from commit e7d1e59283e13da0d6a253df0a29a243444ed58e)

commit_message:
Always convert to docker media format

Previously if the container config mediaType was unset or set to
something other than a docker format, we would just pass that on. This
caused problem with stricter checking of the metadata performed by some
versions of Podman. Since we're always converting the layer metadata
information to docker, we should ensure that the config media type is
properly set to a valid docker distribution format. This change ensure
that when we push the image config, that the mediaType is set to match
the contents type.

Change-Id: I6b6a8231f6881fdb53084a437ee24fd852ebdd55
Closes-Bug: #186585
(cherry picked from commit e7d1e59283e13da0d6a253df0a29a243444ed58e)

subject: Update ro excludes
messages: [{'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2020-02-07 14:50:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch stable/rocky.'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-02-17 17:34:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\ncheck-rdo'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2020-02-19 15:00:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-07 14:50:23.000000000', 'message': "Update ro excludes

When container-puppet.sh (or docker-puppet.sh) runs, we always bind
mount in certain directories and files. However if these files change
while we're running the puppet execution externally on the host, they
end up being copied to our puppet-generated path. This path is copied
into the container when kolla starts up. Because we re-mount these same
paths in the end container as read-only, kolla will try and update the
read-only mount which errors. This change updates our rsync excludes to
include:

 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/extracted
 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.trust.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/cert.pem
 * /etc/hosts
 * /etc/localtime

Conflicts:
        common/container-puppet.sh

Change-Id: I858a7b8745688c6271b01795460ab4adbf3f2be5
Closes-Bug: #1860607
(cherry picked from commit 36ea0148e8b2ed30fb0a03fe6f812fd00657924b)
"}]
commit_message:
Update ro excludes

When container-puppet.sh (or docker-puppet.sh) runs, we always bind
mount in certain directories and files. However if these files change
while we're running the puppet execution externally on the host, they
end up being copied to our puppet-generated path. This path is copied
into the container when kolla starts up. Because we re-mount these same
paths in the end container as read-only, kolla will try and update the
read-only mount which errors. This change updates our rsync excludes to
include:

 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/extracted
 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.trust.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/cert.pem
 * /etc/hosts
 * /etc/localtime

Conflicts:
        common/container-puppet.sh

Change-Id: I858a7b8745688c6271b01795460ab4adbf3f2be5
Closes-Bug: #1860607
(cherry picked from commit 36ea0148e8b2ed30fb0a03fe6f812fd00657924b)

commit_message:
Update ro excludes

When container-puppet.sh (or docker-puppet.sh) runs, we always bind
mount in certain directories and files. However if these files change
while we're running the puppet execution externally on the host, they
end up being copied to our puppet-generated path. This path is copied
into the container when kolla starts up. Because we re-mount these same
paths in the end container as read-only, kolla will try and update the
read-only mount which errors. This change updates our rsync excludes to
include:

 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/extracted
 * /etc/pki/ca-trust/source/anchors
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/certs/ca-bundle.trust.crt
 * /etc/pki/tls/cert.pem
 * /etc/hosts
 * /etc/localtime

Conflicts:
        common/container-puppet.sh

Change-Id: I858a7b8745688c6271b01795460ab4adbf3f2be5
Closes-Bug: #1860607

commit_message:
Enable sudo rule creation

We need to enable users to create sudo rule to enable running restricted
commands via sensubility executor.

Change-Id: I8856d4e17ef0b72446122b764e67b9e8fba4c781
Depends-On: I47c6e4fb3beab14cc5c7f824646e3c2242b140d4

commit_message:
Fix undefined variable in cinder_backup service.

cinder_backup_docker_image_latest ansible variable wasn't
existing anymore, as it was changed into cinder_backup_image_latest.

Change-Id: I0fdef9becf9cc23786180c3399ca09461a916114
Closes-Bug:#1861475
(cherry picked from commit 436ea96660d75fb7a6476b4bd05d954b621fe822)

Correct current cinder-backup image var for upgrades

In I8b5b25d03b86b2c44b2d47e5a0624e7dd13873da an incorrect
variable name was used for cinder-backup. This corrects
the variable.

(cherry picked from commit 4e739f7e71fc1b2dc8a3bdbdc5b83dcd0614a77a)

commit_message:
Add 'scale-up' upgrade steps for cinder-volume

This patch adds the missing steps for 'scale-up' upgrade
support for the cinder-volume service similar to the
implementation in I3cfd4272449b207874723682903505d2bbdb435b

Related-Bug: #1838971
Change-Id: Ib97f3e7508e277d03d3cb75bba640264518b6323
(cherry picked from commit 1044d0bf3dfeff0ffa5929abb07b11a0cb1000de)

subject: Add "convert_output_data" config property for YAQL
messages: [{'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-02-19 08:59:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2020-02-19 08:59:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-02-19 09:20:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2020-02-19 09:21:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 19134, 'date': '2020-02-19 14:12:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-02-19 16:29:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Patch Set 2 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 8731, 'date': '2020-02-19 16:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-19 08:59:26.000000000', 'message': 'Add "convert_output_data" config property for YAQL

* Adding "convert_output_data" config property gives an opportunity
  to increase overal performance. If YAQL always converts an expression
  result, it often takes significant CPU time and overall workflow
  execution time increases. It is especially important when a workflow
  publishes lots of data into the context and uses big workflow
  environments. It's been tested on a very big workflow (~7k tasks)
  with a big workflow environment (~2.5mb) that often uses the YAQL
  function "<% env() %>". This function basically just returns the
  workflow environment.
* Created all necessary unit tests.
* Other style fixes.

Closes-Bug: #1863857
Change-Id: Ie3169ec884ec9a0e7e50327dd03cd78dcda0a39b
Cherry picked from Ie3169ec884ec9a0e7e50327dd03cd78dcda0a39b

commit_message:
Add "convert_output_data" config property for YAQL

* Adding "convert_output_data" config property gives an opportunity
  to increase overal performance. If YAQL always converts an expression
  result, it often takes significant CPU time and overall workflow
  execution time increases. It is especially important when a workflow
  publishes lots of data into the context and uses big workflow
  environments. It's been tested on a very big workflow (~7k tasks)
  with a big workflow environment (~2.5mb) that often uses the YAQL
  function "<% env() %>". This function basically just returns the
  workflow environment.
* Created all necessary unit tests.
* Other style fixes.

Closes-Bug: #1863857
Change-Id: Ie3169ec884ec9a0e7e50327dd03cd78dcda0a39b
Cherry picked from Ie3169ec884ec9a0e7e50327dd03cd78dcda0a39b

[{'created': '2020-01-24 16:49:59.000000000', 'message': 'ovs agent: signal to plugin if tunnel refresh needed

Patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697655/ cannot be backported
because it includes an RPC version change. This patch is for the
stable branches.

Currently the ovs agent calls update_device_list with the
agent_restarted flag set only on the first loop iteration. Then the
server knows to send the l2pop flooding entries for the network to
the agent. But when a compute node with many instances on many
networks reboots, it takes time to readd all the active devices and
some may be readded after the first loop iteration. Then the server
can fail to send the flooding entries which means there will be no
flood_to_tuns flow and broadcasts like dhcp will fail.

This patch fixes that by also setting the agent_restarted flag if
the agent has not received the flooding entries for a network.

Change-Id: Iccc4fe4a785ee042fd76a663d0e76a27facd1809
Closes-Bug: #1853613

commit_message:
ovs agent: signal to plugin if tunnel refresh needed

Patch https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697655/ cannot be backported
because it includes an RPC version change. This patch is for the
stable branches.

Currently the ovs agent calls update_device_list with the
agent_restarted flag set only on the first loop iteration. Then the
server knows to send the l2pop flooding entries for the network to
the agent. But when a compute node with many instances on many
networks reboots, it takes time to readd all the active devices and
some may be readded after the first loop iteration. Then the server
can fail to send the flooding entries which means there will be no
flood_to_tuns flow and broadcasts like dhcp will fail.

This patch fixes that by also setting the agent_restarted flag if
the agent has not received the flooding entries for a network.

Change-Id: Iccc4fe4a785ee042fd76a663d0e76a27facd1809
Closes-Bug: #1853613

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-14 18:50:44.000000000', 'message': 'Workaround in NetworkSegmentRange OVO until "project_id" migration

The "network_segment_range" service plugin API does not have
"tenant_id" as parameter. However, because the migration from
"tenant_id" to "project_id" did not finish, every OVO with
"project_id" will also have "tenant_id" as an extra field. This
extra field will be populated with the same value as the
"project_id" field.

If the Neutron API WSGI is used and "tenant_id" is not present in
the API (defined in neutron-lib), both "tenant_id" and "project_id"
parameters will be removed from the response.

This patch introduces a workaround for this OVO until the migration
is over.

More information about this patch can be found in the bug c#4.

Change-Id: I85a02d8b59e8a758826c110e00df84672fa93676
Closes-Bug: #1828205
'}, {'created': '2020-02-17 12:10:06.000000000', 'message': 'Workaround in NetworkSegmentRange OVO until "project_id" migration

Change-Id: I85a02d8b59e8a758826c110e00df84672fa93676

'}]
commit_message:
Workaround in NetworkSegmentRange OVO until "project_id" migration

The "network_segment_range" service plugin API does not have
"tenant_id" as parameter. However, because the migration from
"tenant_id" to "project_id" did not finish, every OVO with
"project_id" will also have "tenant_id" as an extra field. This
extra field will be populated with the same value as the
"project_id" field.

If the Neutron API WSGI is used and "tenant_id" is not present in
the API (defined in neutron-lib), both "tenant_id" and "project_id"
parameters will be removed from the response.

This patch introduces a workaround for this OVO until the migration
is over.

More information about this patch can be found in the bug c#4.

Change-Id: I85a02d8b59e8a758826c110e00df84672fa93676
Closes-Bug: #1828205

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-02-12 23:22:50.000000000', 'message': "Tell reno to ignore the kilo branch

When reno 3.x runs under setuptools, it scans all of the branches it can
find, including any that look like they're closed and have an -eol tag.
The old kilo branch in this repository has a jumbled history that
somehow makes it look like it should include tags that it doesn't. We
know that there are no release notes in that branch, because reno wasn't
adopted while it was open. The releasenotes/source/index.rst links to
separate release notes in the wiki.

This patch tells reno to ignore that branch so that it doesn't throw an
exception when it gets confused about the old tag.

Change-Id: Idd56c3f37d5786daae7181c36d38d267cbf1885c
Co-Authored-By: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 94b228464dd0c1594c974d333cd31519a48d3761)
"}]
commit_message:
Tell reno to ignore the kilo branch

When reno 3.x runs under setuptools, it scans all of the branches it can
find, including any that look like they're closed and have an -eol tag.
The old kilo branch in this repository has a jumbled history that
somehow makes it look like it should include tags that it doesn't. We
know that there are no release notes in that branch, because reno wasn't
adopted while it was open. The releasenotes/source/index.rst links to
separate release notes in the wiki.

This patch tells reno to ignore that branch so that it doesn't throw an
exception when it gets confused about the old tag.

Change-Id: Idd56c3f37d5786daae7181c36d38d267cbf1885c
Co-Authored-By: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit 94b228464dd0c1594c974d333cd31519a48d3761)

commit_message:
Switch to hacking 2.x

This bumps the version of flake8 and pycodestyle to something much
newer, which resolves a long-standing warning about nested sets and
allows us to use new fangled features like f-strings if we so choose.

Note that this requires some minor modifications to keep the 'pep8' task
passing.

Change-Id: I3af8eb490345a6152372730ca3e0a6702bf482ea
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove six

We don't need this in a Python 3-only world. We can't remove mock yet
since there's an issue with the stdlib variant in python3.6, but that is
called out.

Change-Id: I9657b1fd4409be90d645175a6e177d7e1d2ebac2
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Support Pacemaker

Currently, Keepalived is used for controlling VIP based upon
the healthy check result of HAproxy.

This PS lets kolla-ansible to support Pacemaker as HA manager. It
simply replace Keepalived and Keepalived's current function in
kolla-ansible. User can choose to use Pacemaker or Keepalived
by setting 'enabled_pacemaker' option.

Change-Id: Ia04d47d1b2be4222aa54c0da7e2199db8b21c5b6
Implements: blueprint use-pacemaker-in-kolla

check-rdo'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2020-02-17 00:22:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Code-Review-1

(3 comments)

I had a look into why introspect fails after importing with this playbook.

The introspect error is "Could not find a node for attributes {...list of mac addresses}

The only difference I could see between mistral and ansible imports was the neutron ports were missing. To create these ports, I think it might be required to call convert_nodes_json_mac_to_ports instead of iterating module.params['nodes_json'] directly, like here:

  https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common/src/branch/master/tripleo_common/actions/baremetal.py#L49

If this doesn't create the ports, you'll need to figure out what does :)'}, {'account_id': 15895, 'date': '2020-02-17 09:59:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 13.'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2020-02-18 14:41:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 13: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 15895, 'date': '2020-02-19 09:21:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Patch Set 13 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 9712, 'date': '2020-02-19 10:22:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 7353, 'date': '2020-02-19 17:06:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 14: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Create a node import module and playbook

Moving the import from mistral into ansible
Adding a playbook to do the node import and modules for validating and registering

Story: 2007126
Task: 38183

Change-Id: I46ecb0e46bdeba3496b888a645bc95d86ef58498

commit_message:
Ensure driver error preventing trunk port deletion is logged

When trunk port deletion is attempted but fails because the driver does
not permit it, the logs do not contain the driver error message that
specifies the precise rationale for preventing the trunk port deletion.
Log it explicitly.

Change-Id: I7ed1a742849dfce9e65b8eb36566112501fb0e39

commit_message:
Ensure driver error preventing trunk port deletion is logged

When trunk port deletion is attempted but fails because the driver does
not permit it, the logs do not contain the driver error message that
specifies the precise rationale for preventing the trunk port deletion.
Log it explicitly.

Change-Id: I7ed1a742849dfce9e65b8eb36566112501fb0e39

subject: Fix performance regression due to reduced number of keystone workers

[{'account_id': 16845, 'date': '2020-01-10 19:44:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 16845, 'date': '2020-01-10 19:45:58.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 16845, 'date': '2020-01-10 19:58:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 16845, 'date': '2020-01-11 18:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 16137, 'date': '2020-01-11 18:23:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

This seems like something deployments should be set based on it's requirements. The regression is solely based on the assumption that usage was distributed between the two ports when Keystone was deployed that way.

The more proper way, if something should be changed at all, would be changing the default value to $::os_workers_large"}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2020-01-17 12:10:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

> This seems like something deployments should be set based on it's
 > requirements. The regression is solely based on the assumption that
 > usage was distributed between the two ports when Keystone was
 > deployed that way.
 > 
 > The more proper way, if something should be changed at all, would
 > be changing the default value to $::os_workers_large

I think this is a wrong statement, Tobias. As explained in the commit message, the actual number of worker for that service has decreased with the merge of services - we probably want to ensure we actually have the same number of total workers for keystone - meaning this patch makes sense, and we should probably not change the os_worker value, since it seems to be something used in other locations.

Adding +1 to show support for this change, but there are some questions (and, please, reformat the commit message :))"}, {'account_id': 9098, 'date': '2020-01-21 13:08:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(4 comments)

I do think this should be fixed here in puppet-keystone as well.  Unfortunately, I don't think any of the "$::os_workers_*" values are correct for what we want since they all divide the number of processes by 2 or more (even "$::os_workers_large").

I believe the multiplication used in the patch does have some corner cases that would result in more keystone processes than desired as mentioned in my in-line comments.  I think we should used an approach based off of the "processorcount" (without division) with min and max caps, which is really the logic that we are trying to use.'}, {'account_id': 28223, 'date': '2020-01-21 13:24:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-01-21 14:24:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2020-01-21 14:25:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:
